I had a peach margarita, which for $9, was much bigger than I expected.  

The Antipasti Contadina was quite a spread.  Meats and cheese, artichokes, peppers, sun-dried tomatoes, delicious.  The three of us finished it off just as the pastas arrived.  Well, I was certainly glad I got the smaller size.  The larger Fettucine con Salsiccia alla Vincenzo  was HUGE!  Both dishes were very good, but the Rigatoncelli alla Carlesimo was clearly the winner of the two.  All the flavors went together wonderfully.  I'm not the biggest fan of sun dried tomatoes, but the ones here, both in my pasta and in the Antipasti, were extremely tasty. We finished the smaller portioned dishes, but my friend who ordered the large portion was unable to finish everything.  Obviously, we didn't have room for dessert, through the choices were very tempting.

The waitstaff was very attentive.  Our water glasses were promptly filled.  I could see that the waitress would glance over from the bar ever so often to make sure we were doing well.  

I really enjoyed the experience here.  Great Italian food in North Beach, but off the beaten path just enough so you didn't feel like you are in a giant tourist trap.  And only 1 block to Rogue for some delicious beer :-)
author: Jory R.

description:
I live about half a block from this place and love taking friends here just to make them that much more jealous of where I live. 

This is probably the best Italian food in North Beach. Yes! It really is. Not really that fancy but definitely good solid food. 

Staff is nice and just an overall great place to be.
author: Stitch H.

description: Non-pretentious , great service , awesome food.  Their signature dishes (ones with the "*" are awesome and very Italian.  Love that its away from the touristy North Beach restaurants.  Perfect date night place.
author: Lilian R.

description: Always delicious!  Highly recommend the burrata as you'll never be disappointed. I've been here twice and it's hard to not come back every night.
author: Jason A.

description: Kevin at the bar is awesome. Service is impeccable. The food is outstanding.
author: Zack H.

description:
My boyfriend took me here for Valentine's Day and totally surprised me. Instead of bringing me to some super new, trendy restaurant, he introduced me to a precious SF gem that's been around for decades, tried and true by various city luminaries and generations of regular folks. 

I loved the locale, just beyond the crazed sidewalks of North Beach, on a quiet corner and positively packed with couples and old regulars. Romance was definitely in the air. My boyfriend and I are big eaters, and this place definitely delivered on hearty delicious, classic Italian food. 

First we ordered a gigantic antipasto plate, a killer spread of meats, cheeses, olives and marinated peppers, artichoke hearts and sundried tomatoes. I was in heaven, it was definitely one of the best charcuterie plates I've ever had. Then I tried the cream of carrot soup with garlic croutons, a special of the evening. It was a perfect balance of light fresh carrots blended with cream and spices, it wasn't heavy at all. And the garlicky croutons really hit it out of the ballpark. We tried a meatball swimming in their house made marinara. The sauce was to die for, and while the meatball didn't rival the ones at Emmy's, it was still delicious. By the time we got to our entrées I was pretty stuffed. Isaac ordered the veal scalloppini w garlic mashed potatoes. I got the creamy pesto penne with fennel sausage, sundried tomatoes and spinach. It was HUGE. I definitely ate only a few bites, and finished the rest the next day at lunch, and had garlic breath for quite awhile afterwards. They brought us their signature drink, a warm wine drink with steamed milk and chocolate. It was foamy and not too sweet, the perfect after-dinner drink. 

The service was awesome, and I loved the open kitchen. It really gave the whole place a more intimate feel. Our server brought everything out to us at a perfect pace and the owner seemed to be greeting and bidding farewell to everyone that came in. I can't wait to come back and try their stuffed peppers and ravioli.
author: Laura M.

description:
Trattoria Contadina offers the complete San Francisco experience; lack of convenient parking included.
Walls are lined with autographed photos of B-listers (do they carry their head shots out with them?), though the front of the restaurant overlooks Russian Hill and the trolley line.
The Bruchetta is toasted perfectly and the Roasted Bell Peppers with Cheese is so rich that it could be on the dessert menu.
Gnocci, Ravioli and Fettucine are all excellent pasts dishes and portions are large enough to pass across the table.
author: Jason N.

description:
On a random Wednesday evening some friends and I decided to try this place.  when we walked in it was obvious that many locals frequent this joint.  It's likely that this is the case because parking is really tough in the neighborhood, but ifyou can snag a spot, the definitely try Trattoria Contadina.

One thing that we really appreciated about TC is that we were not charged a corkage fee for our wine.  I don't care what type of restaurant you are, corkage fees should be ILLEGAL!  So big points for TC on this alone.

We started our evening by sharing the spinach salad and the roasted bell peppers with cheese.  Both were extremely yummy.  I was hesitant at first about the bell peppers, but the waiter suggested it so we tried it.  I'm glad we did. It was different and quite tasty.

For my main course I had the gnocci.  I am huge fan of good gnocci and when it's done right (not too dense and flavorful) I get really happy.  On Wednesday, I got really happy :)  The tomato cream sauce for the gnocci was fabulous and the quantity was enough for 1 meal at dinner plus a small lunch the next day.

Side note: my bf had the tortellini which he just devoured and my friend had one of the 2 chicken dishes (I'm not sure which one).  Both were happy with their meals and commented that they were satisfied and look forward to returning.

I love it when I leave a restaurant feeling good :)

The price was fair and the service was also good.
Parking is really bad so cab it if you can.
The ambiance was fun and lively.

Thanks Trattoria Contadina for a nice impromptu meal - and a big hug for not charging a corkage fee!!  

I'll be back soon...
author: DJ N.

description:
What a disappointment!  

Noticing that this place was packed with patrons every time I passed, I thought it must be fabulous and I should give it a try.   My boyfriend and I went to dinner there last night.  We began by ordering a bottle of wine and a drink  When the server returned we ordered two appetizers, then not long after ordered two half orders of pasta and the veal chop.  Here, I have to add that this is the only restaurant I've ever been to that will not substitute one type of pasta for another in a dish, so I was limited in my choices as I hate dealing with  (and tend to make a mess with) long, thin unruly pasta.  

When only one of the appetizers came out we started contemplating how they must be specially configuring the meal based on the odd number of dishes ordered and expected it would certainly come out with one of the pasta dishes in the next course.  When the two half orders of pasta came out, we asked the server and he had forgotten about the other dish.  We decided not to get it.  So then the question became, was I expected to sit with no food while my boyfriend ate his veal chop?  I shared one of the pastas and lingered over the other so as not to sit plateless during the next course when they brought out the last dish.

Most of the food was only okay and the service quite poor.  Perhaps petty, but no freshly ground pepper was offered, nor did the server ever come by and offer to refill our wine glasses.  It just seemed like such a nicer place from the outside.

I can't see any reason to go back.
author: Cristina S.

description: Chicken risotto was OK. Lamb chops were EXCELLENT. Apps great. Dessert great. Service good. Very busy, very small quarters, would recommend getting a reservation. Would recommend.
author: Henry C.

description: Always a go to for a solid Italian meal.  I have found it to be a great place to take family and out of town guests.  The food is authentic and quality is always fabulous.  I recently went there on a Friday night and they were quick to seat us and service was good.  I received a recommendation from a friend to try the stuffed peppers...I was a little hesitant, as I'm not a huge pepper fan, but had to try based on her rave reviews.   So glad I did!  It was FANTASTIC!!  Absolute heaven - and the sauce is so plentiful that they bring you bread to dip after the pepper is gone...I swear, next time I may make this my meal!!  Tip: parking can be tough, so ensure to get there ahead of time to give you ample time to search...it's hit or miss on the weekends.
author: Betsy C.

description: Consistently a great place. This was my third or fourth visit. I love coming here because it is off the main area for North Beach Italian restaurants and it has a more intimate feel. It's sort of feels like a small family kitchen. Everything is fabulous on the menu and it is primarily a place locals in the neighborhood frequent. Not really a place that tourists will find however they would be very pleasantly surprised. The closet bathroom could benefit from a remodel but there is something so charming about how old this restaurant is, and how it still gives off an amazing vibe in spite of not being a new modern decor.  The wonderful aromas from the kitchen are just a prelude to the amazing meal ahead.
author: Joy J.

description: Two friends and I had dinner here on a Thursday night.  I enjoyed it a ton.  Very family-owned and operated atmosphere-- i.e., it had a genuine feel to it.  The lamb chops I had were very good, although well-done and I had ordered medium rare.  Great service.  Prices seemed reasonable.
author: Patrick K.

description: Really nice restaurant, but the food was strictly ok. The service was great and the staff, very friendly. I loved the interiors- warm and cozy- great for a cold, winter evening.  We ordered the pasta with meatballs and the roasted red pepper appetizer. Probably not their best, but i wasn't blown away with the food. I wouldn't mind visiting again, but wouldn't recommend proactively,
author: Megha C.

description: I don't even want to write this review because I feel like it's my hidden secret.  I met Julie at Riccardo's ,found out she is the Chef at Trattoria and that she caters.  I had her cater my sit down New Year's Eve dinner.  I had lasagna, creamy penne pesto, Caesar salad and focaccia bread, with olive tapenade, all home made.  It was hot and so delicious. Thank you and Happy New Year to Julie and her staff!!!  All you foodies, this is the place to check out.
author: Michelle k.

description: Not really sure why this place gets top stars...but my experience was just okay. Came here for mothers day (since this restaurant is one of my mom's favorites in SF) . Was a bit late due to parking (tip: come early!!! valet around the corner gets pricey as hell!!). Originally got the salvatore, but didn't enjoy it and luckily my dad was willing to trade ..so I ate his dish which was called the Carlesimo. It was okay.....wasn't head over heels about it , but def better than the Salvatore that I had. We also ordered the bruschetta (bomb) and some meat platter dish..(salami, etc). The meat platter wasn't too good...it was sour and salty......(tasted straight up like green olives.). Also had some type of seafood pasta, which was okay. Overall I wouldn't say this place is the best italian place I've eaten because I've had better. Service was great, it was a packed house. The food....eh...not so much. Pricing is okay, not too expensive either.
author: Colette P.

description:
This is the best Italian food in North Beach. I highly recommend the specials. They had this amazing salad with shrimp and scallops. It was perfectly seasoned and dressed. The pasta was completely phenomenal. The server was magnificent, informative and friendly. 
I do recommend making reservations. The wine list is very good, A nice combo of old and new world with a few cool surprises.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Trattoria Contadina is a bit off the main Columbus Avenue North Beach strip.  It's a corner place that fills quickly and is obviously popular.  The walls are studded with pictures of celebrities of long ago and celebrity wanna bees of long ago.  The place has a reputation for serving good old time Italian food.  

I start with a small spinach salad that comes with feta cheese, walnuts, cranberries and vinaigrette.  It's an OK plate of food but for the non-too-crunchy walnuts, which must have been around a bit too long.  A half order of spaghetti with meatballs is immense, but not immensely satisfying.  The spaghetti is cooked a bit beyond al dente, the meatballs are dense but largely tasteless and the tomato sauce bland.  

I finish with a grilled veal chop with a balsamic vinegar reduction, red onion and capers sauce, served with fresh sautéed garlic spinach and creamy soft polenta.  The chop cannot stand up to the bitter ill-conceived sauce, the spinach is overly salted, but the polenta is OK.

The menu is strange.  Many main courses come with sides of pasta, making it necessary to skip these if you want a pasta course.  The food seems old fashioned without having the old time subtlety or depth of flavor.
author: David D.

description:
i realllly like this place.

we were told to wait 15 min for a eat.  at 13 min...waitress brings us complimentary bruchetta and is extremely apologetic for the long wait.

bar tender was friendly  but looked like he could destroy you if you got belligerent...just an observation

verde pasta was undercooked

the house red did its job, i dont know wine

complimentary dessert....i dont know why they were so freaking nice

i wore gym clothes without showering and the paper placemats allowed me to draw penises and play tic tac toe while we waited...im 24 years old.
author: Paran Y.

description: One of my favorites when I get up to SF.  The place is fairly small, so can be crowded and a bit loud.  But hey, it's kinda romantic too.  Food and service are 5 star!
author: Steven W.

description: We loved this restaurant. The food was great and the service was excellent. Each recommendation made by the waiter was spot on. Save room for the desserts.
author: Ed C.

description: Trattoria Contadina has an expansive menu with plenty of great choices, a picturesque locale on the cable car line and a little off the beaten track of North Beach, and an interesting, if a little crowded, interior with signed photos from celebrities and athletes. I heartily recommend the gnocchi with creamy tomato sauce. Excellent.
author: Brian B.

description: This place was very delicious and service was great. The waiter brought us fresh bread with olive oil to start. The oil did not have any added seasonings like many chain Italian restaurants do, but my husband was pleasantly surprised that the oil had an "infused" flavor (hard to describe, but kind of like salt and garlic). We both enjoyed the arugula, beet, goat cheese and pistachio salad for an appetizer. I had the halibut, which was served with a wonderful fresh pesto sauce as well as roasted potatoes and garlic broccolini. My husband had the saltimbocca, which was served with mashed potatoes and broccolini. Those sides are without a doubt his two least favorite side dishes, but he enjoyed them. This restaurant is excellent at seasoning their dishes. Everything had just the perfect amount of garlic and we did not leave there feeling "garlicky." We finished our meal with coffee, espresso and a mocha gelato pie. We could not have had a better meal in North Beach and would go back next time we travel to San Francisco. Even thought we are tourists, this restaurant seemed to be filled with primarily locals which is another way to know that it's a well-liked restaurant.
author: Theresa C.

description: This was great food, at a really low price! Our food was piping hot, and incredibly good. They were also very nice about special orders, and switching sauces and such. Their seafood pasta had a perfect ratio of  fish, and pasta. i order this alot at Italian places, and this was one of the best I've had!
author: Amanda G.

description:
Holy ****!!! This place is awesome! I was totally on the yelp reviews on this one. Loved it!! We were super lucky since there were no lines. I guess us being at the doorstep at 5:30 pm sharp does count lol.

Here's what we ate - Ravioli alla Salvatore and Cavatappi con Vitello alla Fratello. The ravioli had chicken, spinach and some herbs and cheese fit in so perfectly with the chicken broth it is served in. It was love at first bite for me. My friend's veal thingy that I refused to taste at first (I am not a baby eater!) had a tasty sauce. Tomato something, I don't quite remember.

We were seated next to a very annoying and rather loud lady (the tables are close to each other) but the food managed to drown that out. So thats how good the food is :)
author: A T.

description: Charming, quaint, slightly off the beaten path and amazing food. My only regret was that I ordered a small instead of a large Carlesimo. The small was plenty of food I just really wished I had more leftovers!
author: Christy C.

description:
Great food!
Nice atmosphere.

5 diners, 1 bottle of wine, 1 appetizer, 5 entrees and 1 dessert  - $140

We had no problem calling in and making a reservation 1 hour before we got there.  That was on a Thursday night 7:15PM for 5.  It is a very small place and all the tables were pretty much full.  Parking can be tough.  We lucked out and found a street spot just up Mason but I guess there is some public parking ~$3.20/each 20 min. around the corner on Powell.  We were seated in a middle round table so there was a lot of waiter traffic going by.  My wife complained that her chair kept getting bumped.  If you can get a table by the window you will have a nice view of the Trolley cars going up/down Mason.

They have a good wine list and a full bar.  You are served fresh hot bread with oil and basalmic vinegar which was very good.  I had a hard time deciding what to order.  I wanted something savory but not too filling.  I chose the small portion Salvatore (Chicken ravioli with sun-dried tomatoes, rosemary, garlic and a marscapone cheese sauce) and I have to say it was very good but I was really dissapointed in the portion size.  It was VERY small compared to the other diners small portions.  I'm glad my wife and I split a large Spinaci Salad (Baby spinach with feta cheese, spiced pecans, sun-dried cranberries and a balsamic vinaigrette) .  It was a good salad.  My wife had the small Pavarotti (Fusilli pasta with sautéed chicken, prosciutto, zucchini, sun-dried tomatoes and a cream sauce)  I wish I had ordered her dish.  It was delicious and seemed like a much larger portion.  My 9 year old daughter ordered the small Gnocchi.  One of the best I've tasted!  I would order that if I go back.  One friend ordered the small Vongole (Linguini pasta with sautéed clams and a lemon, butter, garlic and white wine sauce ) which looked very good.  She was very happy with that.  And our other friend had the large Polpettine (Linguini pasta with Rocky's homemade meatballs and a fresh tomato sauce)  I tell you, his plate was huge!  And it looked awesome.  He was very pleased with his choice.  

For desert we all shared an order of the Tiramasu.  Awesome stuff!  We each easlily had a couple of bites.

Our waiter was very nice and attentive.  We spent about 2 hours there.  Everyone had a enjoyable dinner and the atmosphere was fun.  I would definitely go there again and take out of town guests there as well.
author: JJ S.

description: A traditional North Beach Italian restaurant off the beaten path. Great food, charming ambience, full bar, excellent service and friendly owners. The gnocchi is my favorite. Ideally they'd have a pizza option, but no biggie.
author: Erik X.

description: Four of us dined there on a busy Friday night.  We were all disappointed with what we ordered and felt the food was below average for San Francisco. I ordered the veal scallopini with a porcini mushroom cream sauce.  The sauce was too heavy, not particularly tasty, and it overwhelmed the veal. This was the same with the steak that my husband had.  It was covered in a heavy, uninteresting sauce, and the quality of the meat wasn't that great.  Too bad because I liked the feel of the restaurant and the service was good. But I wouldn't recommend it.
author: Cindy M.

description:
Some observations:

1. Really yummy, hearty Italian Food.  The Risotto, Salmon and chicken dishes are A+.  I recently had the Conchigle Bolognese special - so good!

2. The service was friendly and fast.  I visited recently with a group of girls for a Bachelorette party.  They were kind enough to give us a FREE bottle of champagne.

3. Location - North Beach is always so fun to visit.  The restaurant is located on top of a steep hill and if you sit by the window, you'll get a view of the Powell St. Cable car - a very San Francisco experience

4. Definitely take out of town guests here, but call ahead for a reservation!

5.  I didn't give it 5 stars because the noise level can get a bit loud, especially if you sit near the front of the restaurant
author: eileen r.

description:
Probably one of my all-time favorite restaurants.  While steeped in personal nostalgia, as it's been the location of many amazing and important evenings in my life (including the evening I proposed to my wife), it is also objectively damn good.  The pasta is perhaps the best I've ever had -- it is really the ONE restaurant where I recommend people skip the entree and go with the pasta dish.   The service is impeccable -- great wine recommendations and prompt, personal and non-invasive wait staff.

Tiramisu.  Yes please.
author: Jason B.

description: Ate there 1/1/2012. Very average Italian food. Pasta is not very fresh. Bruschetta was terrible - not fresh and too salty. Bread was dry without much flavor. Service is very friendly and good atmosphere away from bustle of Columbus Ave, however. Tiramisu was terrific.
author: Michael G.

description:
Delicious! Went here with my husband, baby, and two friends. The service was excellent--they were efficient and very helpful with seating our party. The pasta was authentic, flavorful and well-differentiated. The Frutti di Mare was a heaping plate of linguini with delicious sauce and tons of fresh seafood--halibut, clams, mussels, and calamari. Not bad at $21. Others had the pasta with meatballs, and the Pavarotti--fusilli with chicken. YUM! The chicken ravioli was average--not worth ordering again.  The salads were good, nothing too crazy.

Overall--very good Italian food and super service from our waiter Cristobal.
author: KeepItReal I.

description: Loved it.  Stopped in for an early dinner on a Sunday evening and throughly enjoyed the experience.  Starting with a Bruchetta app and then onto the Veal Saltimboca, the food was excellent and service quite attentive. Quant little old-school Ma/Pa joint.  Great food.
author: Gerry K.

description:
This may not be the most obvious or spontaneous choice (just as well, since reservations are strongly recommended!) for most people visiting NB, since it's set away from the Broadway-Columbus bustle, but it well worth going out of the way for!
The 'Pepperoni Arrostiti con Formaggio' (Roasted peppers stuffed with cheese in a tomato cream sauce), and the red bell pepper ravioli (forgot the name, sorry) were outstanding!
Service was very attentive, and the venue itself is charming and cozy.
Parking can be a pain - a word of advice, head north, not south, of the restaurant for better street parking.
author: Godot -.

description:
Amongst the worst Italian food I've had in SF, along with terrible service and an awful atmosphere (you can barely hear the conversation at your own table).

If you're thinking about coming here, don't.
author: Chris Y.

description: Went to this restaurant tonight with some girlfriends!!!  I had the Caprese and the Pavarotti. Awesome nothing to complain about. Glad we tried it out !!
author: shannon w.

description:
We just had a dinner with a large party (over 10) at TC, and we were very impressed.  They were fine with a few of us being a little late due to holiday traffic and immediately seated the early arrivals.   It is a small place, so you definitely want to make reservations if possible.

The service was very friendly and attentive; water glasses were never empty and the bread kept flowing.  

We're not major foodies or wine snobs, but we know tasty Italian food, and we were all happy with out choices.  My ravioli with pesto was hearty and spicy, and my wife's chicken and my mother's halibut both got the thumbs-up.  The desserts were good (my brother's spumoni looked like a piece of art), and we really enjoyed the ambiance and had a good time.  

We were there for about 3 hours with all the courses and festivities  and never felt rushed, and they were really gracious.

I would definitely recommend Trattoria Contadina for a family dinner or a nice dining experience for two.
author: Dave M.

description: Everything I've had here has been excellent.  The roast peppers, meatballs, several pasta dishes, everything.  The meatballs really stand out with a hearty sauce and great flavor.  Yes, they may be simple but it is a lovely simplicity.  The wait staff is very attentive and friendly.  They have quite a family atmosphere developed in the place with all the wait staff appearing to be friends with each other and many of the patrons.  They recognize me by sight and name on my repeat visits.  You can't go wrong with this place.  Kudos to everyone over there.
author: Eric W.

description:
Awesome place off the beaten path! Waiter was friendly, and knowledgeable, food was excellent! Wine list wasn't extensive, but had a variety and affordable! I plan on taking my mom here when she is in town! 

We made reservations for two, but it seemed that the turn time there wasn't too long so I'm sure they can take walk ins. After leaving the restaurant to meet up with my brother and some of his friends who live in SF, (I had just moved here) they informed me that we had just eaten at a Locals Favorite without even knowing! 

Definitely a great place for a date, or dinner out with the girls. The carb diet is back in, right?
author: Caitlin M.

description: A solid place for pastas. I got the Fresco and it was good. Everyone else at my table got pastas as well and seemed to be pleased with their choices. My only word of warning is that the half orders/smaller orders of the ravioli aren't really enough food!
author: Sydney L.

description: This past Saturday (September 28) was my 5th time, and is really the only place I come to have dinner when I visit SF. The food is absolutely the BEST, and Milo is the most awesome waiter EVER! Cannot recommend this restaurant enough.
author: Debbie V.

description: The absolute best Italian food in San Francisco! Kevin and Gina, and all the staff, are the best. The atmosphere is fun, the food is delicious. What more can you ask for?!
author: Shelly R.

description: I came here years ago, and I remember the food being much better than it was when I went a few nights ago.  The place is tiny, and I love the small, intimate feeling of the restaurant.  While a little bit slow, the service was good too.  The antipasti appetzier was super tasty, but I was pretty disappointed with my entree.  The waiter recommended the veal risotto which I ordered since I love both veal and risotto...  The risotto was good but the veal was a little tough.  Something about the entree just didn't come together.  The friends I was with thought it was okay also but not phenomenal.  It's definitely one of the few places in (and around) North Beach that isn't packed with tourists.
author: Wendy L.

description: 5 stars for food (try the beef carpaccio - with arugula and perfect parm and EVOO.) 3 or  4 for the LOUD and crowded atmosphere.  We enjoyed our meal here way back in 1994!!!!!!  Can't wait to see what they are up to nowadays.
author: Karen F.

description:
I just got home from dinner here...amazing!!!! Ok, so i hate mushrooms but they tasted delicious, with the pesto sauce, however everything taste great with pesto. I ordered this dish called Verde, it was incredible, if you love pesto like me, you will die for this dish. Our server was great and nice, and took me and my friends photo before we left.

The food was great and they had a pretty good wine selection divided into categories of Old World Wine and New World Wine, loved it. That was my first time at an Italian restaurant that i would eat almost everything on the menu.The place is small and cute, and everyone seemed to be pleasant even the  customers. 

My only minus, is parking,but then again, if you leave in San Francisco, its part of everyday life! I would suggest though maybe taking the trolley if you are trying to impressing the lady/guy you are taking out that night...lol

It was awesome, i'm sure i'll be there again.
author: Nia W.

description: Amazing!!! Love the cheese ravioli with pesto! Definitely bringing the family back here again. Highly recommend.
author: Leticia R.

description: Good...a bit rich but good service and 'old school' setting with autographed pictures of local celebrities on the wall.   It is off the main drag in North Beach so it gives one a break from the 'Rush,' and is a 'safe' choice for food...just do not expect anything fantastic.
author: Scott E.

description: The reviews kept mentioning how great the staff is and we were not disappointed.  The location can't be beat!  Such a cute spot just off the cable car line.  I was travelling with my 65 year old mother and my sister.  We wanted to be close to transit and have a good meal.  This was exactly what we got. A true San Francisco gem.  I can't say the food was anything other than good hearty Italian fare.  We weren't looking for anything too creative so the menu was what we expected.  We had beef ravioli with the tomato cream sauce and Chicken Parmesan.  The cheesecake for dessert was tasty as well.
author: Kelsey F.

description: I came here with my wife and another couple before heading to a comedy show. The food was pretty good, but the restaurant is a bit cramped. I'll admit that Italian isn't my favorite cuisine so maybe I'm not the best judge. We got the pesce marsala and Saltimbocca. Street parking is always painful in North Beach and I don't think they have any valet. Sorry can't remember. But there are a few garages nearby that aren't too expensive. Only problem is most of them close pretty early.
author: Michael H.

description:
I love Trattoria Contadina.  Everything I have tried here is outstanding and the service is efficient and friendly.

We had the Melanzane which is fantastic if you like eggplant.  The Valdostana was very good as well.  But my favorite is the pasta Carlesimo.  Perfectly cooked and the sauce is fantastic.  I think I could eat it every day.

The atmosphere is intimate and cozy and they make you feel very welcome.  One of my favorite italian restaurants in SF.
author: Andrew R.

description:
Mixed feelings about this place. 

The good:
A local joint so not so many tourists. The food was tasty. Raviolis are favorites and I had the salmon over linguine that was done just right. They did a great job of serving all nine of us almost at the same time. 

The bad: 
It was really crowded upstairs and my chair kept getting bumped by the server. Bad air circulation.

The ugly:
My friend saw a mouse, mentioned it to a bus boy, he laughed, then the waitress almost stepped on it and freaked out. None of us were sick afterwards but it made us feel a little queasy. We didn't stay for dessert.
author: Kat H.

description:
Yelp did not steer me wrong on this one - this is the best little Italian place I have been to in North Beach. One must absolutely skip the flash of the Columbus and Broadway joints and get a few blocks over to some real good food.

I didn't make reservations, so we wound up at the bar, which is cool, the service was absolutely awesome. Fast, friendly, knowledgeable and accommodating, couldn't ask for better service. The food is similarly fantastic. I have on a few occasions had better, call it 4.5 on the food, but the overall experience makes up for less than perfect food. It is really, really good food.

Make a reservation, or sit at the bar, but be sure to make this is a first choice in the North Beach area.
author: Ben K.

description: This is absolutely the best restaurant in San Francisco!  The food and the service are spectacular!  As soon as you walk in the door you realize that you stepped foot into a true San Francisco staple.  There are a lot of great tables along the window where you can watch the cable cars go by.  The best advice I can give is to get (anything) with the spicy tomato cream sauce!  I have lived in the neighborhood for years and I never get a better reaction from out of town guest than I do when I bring them to Trattoria Contadina!  The bartender pours excellent beverages and the GM is always in the house to make sure your dining experience is flawless!  I highly recommend going to this restaurant!!
author: Matthew T.

description:
I think that you really can't go wrong with Italian food. That's why I tend to be a bit more critical when it comes to Italian restaurants, which means that three stars aiint so bad. 

I visited SF this past weekend, and Trattoria Contadina was what we hoped would "make" our Little Italy experience.  Although the food was pretty decent (big portions and pretty tasty), the restaurant itself was far from the hustle and bustle of North Beach.  After a pretty good dinner, we headed more towards the heart of North Beach, and realized that we may have missed out on some of the NB hotspots.  

Nevertheless, our experience at Trattoria Contadina was a good one.  The staff was very helpful and kind, and the food was good.  We didn't really check out the wine list too much b/c we had just spent an entire day at Napa, but the food list was pretty extensive.  I ended up ordering the Fettucini, which was good, but the crowd favorite was the Rigatoncelli.  That dish was really special... lots of strong flavors going on. 

Overall, I would say that it's a restaurant worth visiting, but if you're in town for a few days, I would recommend checking out some other restaurant closer to the center of NB.
author: Emily C.

description:
My brother's friend's girlfriend's mother, or something like that, actually recommended this place - and WOW what a find!  I'd thank them if I could figure out who actually tipped us off to this little gem!

Here's the background - it was my parents' 40th wedding anniversary, so we all converged in SF for the weekend (plus it was B2B weekend so why not!).  Bro and I picked this place for dinner, made reservations, and got a present for the 'rents.  Had drinks at the hotel, gave said present (they cried), and took a cab to dinner.  We ran late but called ahead, and they had no problem pushing the reservation back (no attitude here!).  

It was HOT, and there was no AC, but since this kind of heat isn't exactly typical for the Bay Area, I won't hold it against the Trattoria.  We luckily had a table by the door.  And a round of mojitos helped cool us "kids" down.  

So the food.  Oh, the food.  So tasty.  Enough in the portions to satisfy the boys, yet not too overwhelming for the gals.  We started with brushetta (yum!) and a caprese salad to share - the tomatoes were fresh and plump and tasty.  The cream sauce with the gnocchi was to die for, and I loved my bow tie pasta with veggies and chicken.  So often veggies are over or under done when tossed with pasta - but not here.  The BF scarfed down his veal (not my favorite usually but even I enjoyed it!).  

We cleaned our plates and headed into dessert - but as it was after a bottle of wine and the aforementioned mojito, things started to get a little fuzzy in the ole noggin.  All I know is that we ordered 3 desserts and each one was spectacular.  

At this point the friendly waiter must have overheard us toasting our parents, wishing them a happy anniversary.  He quickly brought over 2 little glasses of limcello (spelling?) for them, on the house, and wished them well.  It was the perfect ending to a perfect evening filled with good food, happy family, and a friendly wait staff.

Then we tried to flag down a cab for the next half hour.  But that's another story!
author: Tess R.

description:
It is just plain really good.
Give it a whirl if you haven't.
Home style Italian at it's best, fresh made pasta, great service. 
Hoping to go back soon
author: Julia T.

description: Nice and solid. Nothing too outrageous, their homemade spicy cream sauce is nice. Very reasonable prices, nice to have meal for two under 80 I believe..Friendly service, good for catching up with friends type place.
author: Tom W.

description:
Fantastic little neighborhood gem with a unique, seasonal menu and staff that makes you feel like home. Mixed in between the trendy and the wealthy restaurants of the always lively North Beach district, you won't find a better warm meal, with a better group of people. Dinner is a mix of unique creations of chicken, veal, seafood, pastas & the usual antipasta + appetizer. Follow up your dinner with a home made tiramisu or their unique chocolate raspberry heart. Once, they had a 'calamari steak', and I've been dying for it to return...
 
So far, this restaurant has lived up to two Valentine's Day dinners, 2 birthday parties, and 1 general dinner. I'm looking forward to many more:)
 
Brady J. Frey
http://bradyjfrey.com
author: Brady F.

description:
I had dinner here with my husband on a saturday night.  Definitely a place requiring a reservation, which we had. Service was good, and the arugula/beet/goat cheese salad was excellent. I wish my special shrimp fusilli pasta had been equally good. The flavors were somewhat bland, and the temperature was lukewarm. 
Because it is crowded, they rush people through, and the dining experience is not very relaxing. Other diners seemed to be enjoying themselves, and I might come back another night and try something else.
author: Leslie C.

description:
After seeing the signed photo of Kirstie Alley on the wall, I can only imagine that eating the delicious food at Trattoria Contadina is what eventually made her The Fat Actress.

My girlfriend and I went here last night for date night and had an excellent experience.  We arrived fifteen minutes prior to our reservation, but were still seated immediately.  Fresh bread and first press olive oil were brought post haste and we enjoyed it a good deal.

The waitress suggested a nice Chianti and we ordered the Bruschetta, which was excellent.  For entrees, I had the veal chop with garlic spinach and polenta.  Spinach was perfectly cooked without being soggy and the polenta was rich and creamy without being too runny or chunky.  The veal chop was also delicious, though a bit overwhelming as it was smothered in salty capers and pickled onions.  Still quite enjoyable. 

My lady had the egg fettuccine with onions, peppers, Italian sausage.  Pasta perfectly aldente, veggies fresh, sauce just right.

A delicious housemade tiramisu finished the meal.  We will definitely be back for more.
author: Evel K.

description:
My search for good, authentic Italian food in the Bay Area continues.

I thought Trattoria Contadina would have put an end to this search.  I heard so many good things about it via Yelp that I thought SURELY, this would be the place where I could get a nice dish of chicken parmigiana with a side of pasta.  That's all I was looking for.  Well made food, tasty, classic.

After driving around looking for parking for at least 15 minutes and failing miserably we decided to park in a lot nearby which cost $10.  It was frustrating from the start.  

We finally arrived, starving and excited.  We sat down at a corner table ready to eat our faces off.  We were brought bread and a little bowl of olive oil.  The bread was cold, crustless and one-dimensional (i.e., of extremely mediocre quality considering the PLETHORA of amazing bakeries that are generously peppered throughout San Francisco).  The olive oil was fine...nothing to write home about.

The waiter was pleasant and brought us menus.  I surveyed the options and found many favorites from my NY restaurant days listed, which was exciting.  No chicken or veal parmigiana which was disappointing and surprising but I was willing to go with something else, like the veal saltimbocca which was labeled a house favorite.  Thing was, it was served with veggies and mashed potatoes.  Now that's fine, of course, and totally normal; but when I asked if they could replace the potatoes with pasta, I received an absolute no.  Wow, I thought to myself....I've never experienced that in New York.  As a cook myself and a member of the food service industry, I understand and APPRECIATE when restaurants truly stick to their culinary choices.  But I've had saltimbocca with pasta on many occasions, and trust me, its not that unusual.  But ok, no big deal, I just figured I'd find something else on the menu that looked good.

Since I was in the mood for pasta I ordered the one meat dish that was served with pasta:  the "Santi" which is (from their website) "Sautéed chicken breast, topped with white mushrooms, pancetta, shallots, and a creamy, sun-dried tomato, vodka sauce, served with penne pasta."  It sounded tasty and different and I figured hey, why not.  My dining partner ordered the "Pavarotti" which was "Fusilli pasta with sautéed chicken, prosciutto, zucchini, sun-dried tomatoes and a cream sauce."

Our food arrived in a short amount of time, less than 15 minutes, and our water glasses were always filled.  When our food arrived, both plates were sprinkled generously with curly italian parsley...which was just plain confusing.  Freshly grated cheese was placed on both dishes, a nice touch.  The issue came when we both tried our food.  Mine was rich, but needed salt and pepper, and was wildly overloaded with sun-dried tomatoes, pancetta and shallots.  it felt as though I was fighting those things in order to get to the pasta and chicken.  The chicken itself was cooked well and the pasta ok, but the sauce was mostly bland.  PLUS...it was supposed to be a vodka sauce but it was WHITE!  Vodka sauce is a mixture of tomato sauce and cream and vodka...its not a white sauce.  What's going on, Contandina?  

My friend's food, to be blunt, tasted like Kraft Macaroni and Cheese.  I thought she was joking at first, or maybe being a bit of an exaggerator, but when I tasted it I realized she was totally right.  Mac and Cheese.  Unreal.

We were both, needless to say, disappointed in our meals.  When we were finished we totally passed on dessert and got out of there as soon as possible.  The $10 fee for parking just added insult to injury.  I paid over $30 for an INCREDIBLY mediocre meal that I could have made asleep, blindfolded, and - likely - over a campfire.  

Do yourself a favor; if you want really good Italian food, please don't go to this place.  You'll be disappointed.
author: Salaams M.

description:
This is a great little, and I mean little restaurant. We had great service, and amazingly fresh food. I split the salmon with my boyfriend. The generous portions made this easy, and left plenty of room for an appetizer and desert. Our waiter was very quick and very educated on the food and the menu.

Recommendations from our table include: the salmon, the ravioli, the veal (they have 4 different kinds)

Tips: Large groups, make a reservation. Parking is difficult and there aren't any close lots, so walk it or cab it.
author: Aubrey W.

description:
Busy place, I think there may have been at least 3 parties going on, the night I decided to go.
Anyhow despite the crowd, our food was delicious, & the service exceptional!
author: Ryoko Y.

description:
I took some friends from out-of-town to Contadina last weekend for some simple Italian food.  The joint is a nice slice of North Beach, but the food got mixed reviews.  My friends' gnocchi w/fennel cream sauce and the risotto were delicious, but my veal w/mushrooms, garlic mash potatoes and truffle spinach was completely lacking any flavor.  Whoever was working the meat station that night, needs to be introduced to the salt and pepper shaker.  The other person in our party had the angel hair pasta w/tomatoes & basil.  It's a pretty basic dish and was good, but nothing to write home about.

Overall, I think Trattoria Contadina is good with their pastas or primi piattis, but their meats or secondis need some work.
author: ChaChaCha ..

description:
I've lived in North Beach for three years. I've learned in these past three years that all the Italian restaurants on Columbus suck. Touristy joints with cheesy waiters (ok the cheese is sort of amusing at times), and mass produced pasta.

Then, there's Trattoria Contadina. There's a reason this place is Zagat rated AND Michelin guide recommended. The Rigatoncelli alla Carlesimo is AMAZING. That's the only reason why this review is getting five stars, actually. Hands down the best pasta dish ever. I love that the rigatoncelli is homemade. Mmmmmm. (so is the gnocchi and ravioli, both of which I've tried...but the rigatoncelli is the best).
author: serena l.

description:
Went here based on the reviews in yelp. A pretty good place. Will definitely go back.

Some yelpers complained about how close the tables are, but I find it to be okay. Guess it's because I've been to a place where the tables are waaay closer (Risotteria in NYC). So, no problem here. Service was alright too. 

I got the rigatoncelli while my friend ordered the fusilli pavarotti (the one with the chicken in a cream sauce). I actually liked my friend's food better. Don't get me wrong, the rigatoncelli was good.. but found the sauce a bit too salty. So, will order the fusilli next time. =)

The best thing about the dining experience here though was the wine. Got a glass of their rose (Lagrein Rose). It was soooo good. I actually went home, searched it online, and was on the waiting list to get one from K&L wine store. =P Highly recommend it.
author: Poof S.

description:
Not too much to add that hasn't been covered already in other reviews, but there is one thing which bears sharing.

So when our pasta arrived, the waiter made the customary offer of freshly grated parmigiano cheese, bearing a box grater and an impressive hunk of parmigiano roughly the size and shape of your average brick which he was grasping at one end. He then proceeded to grate with some vigor over my pasta, but within just one or two seconds, the grating ruptured a heretofore unknown hairline fracture in the cheese and sent an entire half of the hunk hurtling towards my face. It hit right above my lip, and let me tell you from personal experience, parmigiano is designated a hard cheese with good reason. So I'm sitting in shock with a hunk of cheese in my lap, little cheese gratings everywhere, and a vague sense that I had just gotten punched in the face.

The waiter seemed quite embarrassed about it, understandably. It did make for a less enjoyable meal, but it's not like I think it's something to blame on anything but a freak accident. They did comp dessert.

So the lesson to be learned here is less about Contadina (see other reviews about that), and more about the dangers of hard cheeses. Make sure you have a firm grasp on a reasonably sized block, and grate at an angle which precludes the generation of leverage sufficient to launch chunks of cheese at high velocity.

Good pasta though.
author: Kevin L.

description:
This is some of the best Italian food I've ever had.  My roommate works for the Four Seasons and somehow got a gift certificate here so she kindly took all of my household there.  We got wine, appetizers, entrees, and desserts and they were all fabulous.  I don't think of the 7 or so dishes we got between all of us, one of them was bad, or not amazing...  

It is on the pricey side so I don't think I would come on my own but its great for a special occasion!
author: Angela S.

description:
On the top of my list and one of my favorites for Italian food.  They serve traditional Italian dishes with a flare.  Their pasta is always made fresh and I've never been disappointed by a dish.  The most recent have been the Ravioli Ceratini (w/ sundried tomatoes) & Salvatore (w/ mushrooms) (sp?).  Both were excellent.

Trattoria has a cozy atmosphere and it's conveniently located off the North Beach strip; fostering an environment of locals  rather than tourists.
author: Ken F.

description:
I've been meaning to check out this restaurant for the past three years. Every time I'm on the 45 or in a taxi heading to the Marina I look out the window and see it and make a mental note to remember it as an option next time I'm heading out to dinner. 

Well, the night finally came last night. My boyfriend and I had spent about an hour drinking hooch lichee vodka sodas and making lists of our favorite things to do in the city for an upcoming friend's visit. We were getting a good buzz going and I realized that there was no way we would be able to make it all the out to the Richmond to eat at Shabu House. 

We needed somewhere closer and my BF wanted somewhere we hadn't been before, and that's when he said, "what about that place you've been talking about going to forever?" So we spent another few minutes debating what streets it was at and then looking for the name on Google. 

Long story short, we figured it out, walked over (one block over and two blocks down) and got seated at a nice table by the door (great for the breeze since it was so hot last night). We started with cocktails and the eggplant, mozzarella, and basil appetizer. It was fantastic.

The waiter recommended a special pasta that had porcini mushrooms, a wine sauce and a few other things. The pasta was al dente and pretty good overall. At this point we had ordered another round of cocktails and were talking more then eating, but we enjoyed sharing the pasta (which was definitely big enough to share).

Overall, this place is cute and feels like a neighborhood restaurant. I want to bring my parents next time they're in town and I will probably make it one of my local spots.
author: Jackie G.

description: The food and service here are fantastic; we were treated like royalty.  I learned about this place on a date awhile back, and I spent considerable time looking for it again.  Now that I've found it, I'll be back to eat my way through the entire menu!
author: Kristine Kris C.

description: Great Italian food that is affordable. The place is a bit small inside for large parties but overall good.
author: Mariange R.

description: Great Italian choice in North Beach. We came here on a recommendation of a friend and were not dissapointed.  The appetizers were great and the pastas were wonderful, especially the Salvatore.
author: Jeff R.

description: An old standby.   It's a bit crowded and noisy, but in a genuine Italian way--just as in Italy, you may find yourself getting to know your neighbors.  The food is solid, more southern than northern style (ie., lots of sauces, on the rich side).  Warm, cozy atmosphere, and actually pretty romantic despite the crowded feel.
author: charles h.

description: Excellent food and attentive service with a fun vibe. Reasonable wine prices for quality wine, and homemade pasta dishes that are fantastic.  We had the carlisemo and gnocchi along with the  caprese appetizer.  If you want authentic high quality Italian food you will find it here. Love their support of small vineyards in Italy!
author: Bruce J.

description: Amazing! Carlesimo is one of my favorite pasta dishes I've ever had anywhere.So good that sometimes I get a to-go order for to bring back to San Diego with me. The pepper appetizer is also really tasty.
author: Stefon M.

description:
My wife took me here earlier this week before heading in to see Beach Blanket Babylon (we've lived here for 15 years and have never seen the show!)  We had a wonderful meal - it was a great start to our evening.

For ambiance and staff courtesy / friendliness, these guys get a 5+ star rating.  We had a great little table next to the window so my wife could do all the people-watching she wanted.

We started with cocktails (a mojito and cable car) which were well made and served promptly.   The star of the meal was actually the appetizer - we split the Pepperoni Arrostiti, which apparently they're known for - it was excellent!  It's basically a yellow bell pepper, roasted, layered with cheese, and simmered in a spicy tomato cream sauce.  It was so good we ordered extra bread just to dip in the sauce!  The waitress, on seeing how much we liked it, was kind enough to explain its origin - and even let us look at the recipe book so we could jot down how it was made!

Our entrees were a mixed bag - one good, the other disappointing.  I had the Valdostana, which had wonderful flavor despite the chicken being slightly overcooked.  The vegetables were perfectly cooked & seasoned and worked very well with the dish.  My wife, however, had the risotto special (porcinis & marsala) and was rather disappointed - it was quite bland without any of the flavors either of us expected.  

In the end, we'd definitely go back - the meal was great with just the one exception, the ambiance was lovely, and the wait staff was extremely friendly.
author: Nathan E.

description:
What a great night! It was my parent's last night in town and we went here for dinner. The menu was huge and none of us could decide what to eat. Portions are huge and prices are not. Really nice local vibe with good service.

Best of all? The food was great!
author: Rachel G.

description:
I really did want to give this place 5 stars after trying it for my first time, especially after all the raving reviews and friends' recommendations.  If it wasn't for the so/so service and lack of tomatoes (more on that later), I would've given it 4 stars.  The food was truly good,and our party of 6 ordered a range of dishes from standbys (spaghetti and meatballs) to the more new, creative dishes.  

There were a few bummers that plagued the night that lent itself to a 3 star rating.  First off, we attempted to order bruschetta and were told they were out of tomatoes.  Huh? Out of tomatoes at an Italian restaurant?  Then we tried to order carpaccio, and were told that our initial choice was out as well, but they had a second option which we decided to try.  (and it tasted like salami).  The dinner part was delicious.  Then we get to dessert.  5 of the 6 people ordered coffee/cappuccinos, and we received 4.  After 10 minutes of wondering where the 5th one was and if by chance the cappuccino machine broke, we had no other option but to interrupt our waiter eating dinner at the next table with the other waiters to inquire.  It wouldn't have bothered me as much if he had apologized and jumped from his chair, but we were met with a look of annoyance instead.  

Bummer.
author: Mrsdubyah W.

description:
I've been going to this restaurant for nearly 8 years.  When Gino at Molinari Deli recommends a restaurant...you listen and go! 

My only regret is that I no longer live in the city and can't frequent Contadina as often as I used to.  Contadina appreciate regulars, and they really care about their customers.  

I highly recommend the Carlesimo Pasta, the Radicchio and Arugula salad, the Tiramisu and any recommended Italian wine (we have never been disappointed).

You can take a closer look at their menu by going to their website (there are too many dishes for me to mention...but I had to point out my favorites).
author: Syma K.

description:
After hearing countless friends recommend dining at Trattoria Contadina, I decided to give it a whirl when my sister and her boyfriend were visiting me from the Midwest.  Following a full weekend of all things San Francisco and sampling food at rather expensive and more "fussy" establishments, my guests said they wanted simple no-stress Italian food.  Trattoria Contadina is a relatively spartan establishment, nothing stuffy or designer providing the feeling that you are in some local's kitchen in Italy (complete with family photos, memorabilia, maps, etc.)  Dining is definitely cozy, accommodating most guests downstairs with some seating in an upstairs balcony.

The staff members are fantastic; completely amenable and personable.  The hostess was kind enough to squeeze us in last minute and our waiter Dilo made decisive suggestions on the menu.  

Prices are pretty reasonable with appetizers and starter salads ranging from 9-15, pasta dishes at 9-21, and main dishes in the mid-to-upper 20's range.  Wine can be purchased by the glass and a menu of Italian-inspired cocktails adds interest.  

My party all left very full and satisfied with the experience.  If you seek a comfortable environment with real, honest Italian food (NOT touristy and not adulterated) then try this place out.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Five stars....go away! This place has been one of my favorite hidden gems for the past seven years. Clearly no longer a "hidden gem" it is wonderful to see a neighborhood establishment thriving and not resting on its laurels. Every dish is a treat.

One day I'll be able to identify more than half the people on the wall!
author: Nigel E. S.

description:
After decades of eating dinner here this has now become our go to for weekend BRUNCH.  We live in the neighborhood and it's not only convenient it's the best food, value and service.  Our three teenagers are constantly asking to go to brunch there and there is something for everyone.
Kevin & Gina have done a great job bringing a nice mix of traditional - THE best bloody mary ever (balsamic glaze rim w/ salt & pepper & celery salt), waffles,  a burger and salad as well as fun egg dishes (eggs in purgatory) and an amazing breakfast wrap.  Don't miss the deviled eggs or the zucchini bread which comes with a home made pear compote and honey butter.
I'm dying to walk by the foolish line of tourists that wait for 90 minutes to get into Mamas and tell them they should just walk up the hill to the Trat.  But then it could become the next place with the line out the door and selfishly I don't want that!
author: Fay C.

description: Classic SF Italian cafe in North Beach. You do not stay open as long as they have serving average food.  We found the staff and service to be excellent. We had no reservation and walked in, they were packed so we said we would eat at the bar, however a few minutes later we were given a small table in the front...perfect eating location. We had the lasagna and the veal...both outstanding! Wine was reasonably priced as we found a nice bottle of chianti for $33.  I highly recommend eating for a classic SF dining experience
author: Jim S.

description: The best fresh and handmade sauce- evah! Small and cozy atmosphere, fabulous drinks and great waitstaff. Certainly a must for a visit to San Fran!
author: Carole M.

description: So I swear I don't weigh 500lbs but from what I'm about to write in this review you might think otherwise. I'm an SF native and have been a regular (much to Kevin & Gina the owners chagrin I surmise) at Contadina for the better part of a decade now. I've had everything of their menu and now had the to die for BRUNCH menu in almost it's entirety. From the zucchini bread to eggs in purgatory to the Benedict, it's all super consistent and leaves you not wanting for anything by the end of your meal. If you've been in for dinner, don't forget about this 30+ year family restaurant that finally opened for brunch after the locals begged for it. Hangover cure, done!! Not to mention great people behind the farm to table food!!!!
author: Stephanie M.

description: No problems, always great, pasta, and people!    simple pasta simple prices great staff great local place!  the meatball pasta is great ravioli chicken w cream sauce rocks, best buy for the price great food people place
author: todd s.

description: This place looked cute.  It's got a real homey atmosphere.  The food wasn't so great.  My wife got the house special risotto and did not like it at all.  It did kind of smell like a wet rag, tasted bland, and had a milky consistency.  My pasta "Vincenzo" was solidly mediocre.  The tiramisu was pretty average.  Definitely not the best I've had.  The drizzled chocolate sauce was more of a diversionary tactic than a complement.  This meal was maybe worth 50 or 60 bucks, but came to 140 for 2 people.
author: Ken M.

description: This was a great find!  Bad for parking, but once we got there, the dinner was awesome.  They let us eat for 3 hours!  We did it all - 2 appetizers, bread, dinner, and dessert.  All was fab.  There was even people sitting next to us speaking Italian.  I felt like I could have been in Italy.  I had the fish of the day (Halibut Picatta?).  It was excellent - light and tasty!  The dessert was the best part.  We shared a salted nut toffee crusted gelato.  To die for!!!  It is a tight fit in this place and noisy.  Can't recommend for very little kids or seniors who have trouble getting around.
author: Shelly M.

description: Cozy traditional family restaurant with all the typical Italian dishes. Great service and good, but not great, food. Contadina is a good break because it's tucked away from the tourist-filled Italian restaurants on Columbus.
author: Anuj S.

description:
Meh...

The bread comes out cold and hard.  I could knock someone out with this thing.  You automatically get a side of olive oil to dip in, but no balsamic to balance it out.  While the Melanzane alla Mozzarella was extremely tasty, I don't think a couple of one inch slices of eggplant should cost $9.  Their special asparagus puree soup was the highlight of the whole meal for me.  Perfectly seasoned and very rich.

For the entrees, the Tortellini alla Panna was a disappointment.  There's al dente and then there's barely cooked, and my tortellini was hard and extremely chewy.  In hindsight, I should have sent them back.  The Ravioli Correnti on the other hand was perfectly cooked, though the sauce was over-powering.

The service in and out of the kitchen left  something to be desired as well.  We had to repeatedly ask for water and it took 20+ minutes from ordering to get a bowl of soup.
author: Max F.

description:
A few months ago, we purchased a gift certificate at the Greyhound Rescue Silent Auction for this restaurant and last night we finally ventured over, after years of saying "We really have to try this place."

We had a 7 p.m. reservation.  We got there about five til and the friendly hostess seated us immediately.  However, it took a long, long time for the server to take our drink order, and when she took it, she took our entire order.  She was pretty short with us, "Hi, what can I get you?"  It felt a little rushed. However, I looked around and saw she had three big-tops, so I know she was just busy.  She wasn't rude or anything, she was just in a hurry.

My husband had scotch, and we ordered a bottle of wine. It took a while to get our drinks, but after that, it was smooth sailing.  And after her other tables calmed down, our server was friendly and attentive.  The busser kept our waters filled, which was great.

We started with the Carpaccio de Manzo, which was thinly sliced filet mignon with capers, parmasan, etc.  It was good, but it was sliced a little too thin, if you ask me.  I also ordered a caeser salad because I've been craving one like mad lately, I have no idea why.

Our server brought the salad already divided up for my husband and me.  She seemed to intuit that we were going to share.  Extra star for her psychic abilities.

For our main courses I had one of the specials, sauteed scallops with seasonal vegetables, fresh tomatoes, and potatoes. It was delicious. The sauce on it was really, really good and the tomatoes really did taste fresh.  My husband had the tortellini alla panna, which was stuffed with pork, sausage, spinach and cheese in a prosciutto and cream sauce.  It was also delicious.

After dinner I had pumpkin cheesecake and he had a pecan topped creamy thing. I can't remember the name, but apparently it's not on the menu all the time.  The pecans were a crunchy candied crust on top of a creamy pudding-like thing.  It was insanely good.

The lighting was low, the seating intimate, a good place to take a date.

All in all, we were very happy, and we'll definitely be back, which is saying a lot because we live in North Beach and always want to try a new place we haven't been before.  This place is worthy of a repeat visit.
author: Jamie C.

description:
Visited this local North Beach Italian restaurant on Monday. We sat at the bar (only fits 3 people) before taking our seats. The bartender was very nice and made a great drink for my date and I (even gave her the additional cosmo portion). 

We sat upstairs, which was great, even though it was a little loud. They ran out of the caprese so we opted for the peppers w/ mozzarella - they were fantastic! A little abundant with the cheese, but overall very good. Our main course was also very good, but it was tough to finish! Overall, I'd definitely recommend this restaurant.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
The boy and I came here relatively late for a weekend night, and we were the last let in before they started closing up the kitchen.  The waiters were attentive and helpful, the pasta was delicious, and they gave us some free "Italian tea" with our dessert ... sure tasted an AWFUL lot like a shot of whiskey.

Anyway, it was a charming little place off the tourist path, and I would definitely go again.
author: Kristen H.

description:
I was pretty disappointed by my experience here. I am relatively new to town and my parents were in for a visit. Tired of soliciting recommendations every time I need to go out, I decided to trust my fellow yelpers. All I can say is: eh. 

The location and and ambiance were promising - it's a bit off the beaten path in North Beach. The service was lacking - we sat for a while before the waitress came expecting our entire order, not just drinks. I got a pasta with chicken,  prosciutto,  sun dried tomato and cream sauce which was super bland. My parents each got veal, which they also reputed to be bland. My dad's came with red sauce and was served with garlic mashed potatoes. Kind of odd. As he said, "it was begging for pasta."  

I won't be back here on purpose, but not will I run screaming if someone offers to take me. I think the fact that none of the celeb photos on the walls have been updated since the early 80s kind of says it all.
author: Erin B.

description:
This and Venticello are my favorite Italian restaurants.  

T.C.  has a great atmosphere.  Right off the cable car line but far enough away from lot of the crap on Columbus.  You have to love the autographed celebrity pictures that adorn the walls. 

Do not go there without ordering the Pepperoni Arrostiti con Formaggio as an appetizer -- roasted peppers in a tomato cream sauce.  It is out of this world.
author: Patrick G.

description:
With all the positive reviews, I was expecting a lot more from Trattoria Contadina.  Overall, I felt it was an average Italian restaurant.

The portions were generous - the Insalata Caprese was yummy and fresh, but the Frutti di Mare alla Fiore was only ok...huge portion, but the pasta was overcooked (tasted like leftover pasta) and the clams were overdone.  My husband ordered the Ravioli alla Salvatore so I sampled some of the ravioli - his dish was done better than mine...the ravioli tasted fresh and it was a generous size (it wasn't one of those ravioli dishes that had 3 or 4 raviolis...it was a bunch of smaller, but well-stuffed raviolis...too many to count!)

Service was a tad slow, too - we were going to order a dessert, but after waiting 25 mins, we decided to just ask for the bill instead.

Despite my disappointing experience, I'm willing to try this restaurant again...the place was packed and seems to be pretty popular, so I'll give it another shot when I'm in North Beach.
author: T G.

description: Met a friend here for dinner.  Had the Carlesimo, the signature dish.  It was delicious.  Pancetta, porcini, sun dried tomatoes and a slightly spicy tomato sauce is full of flavor.  Restaurant is somewhat small, but we were easily accommodated at 6.  Dishes are reasonably priced and you'll have leftovers.  Would definitely return.
author: Kristen V.

description: Had the fish special. It was very flavorful with the right balance.
author: Ed C.

description:
If you're looking for an unpretentious, old-skool kind of Italian food, Contadina is your place. No fusion, no fuss. Just warm, cozy atmosphere, attentive service (they always let you try wines), and put-meat-on-your-bones food. 

I highly recommend the Rigatoncelli alla Carlesimo, which came in a spicey tomato cream sauce with fresh peas, sun-dried tomatoes and pancetta. The pasta was perfectly al dente and the appetizer portion size was more than enough. The tiramisu for dessert was not too sweet but decadent nonetheless.

The table next to us inquired about what was in the sauce on the lamb chop, and the server came back with the ingredients written out by the chef. How cool is that? If you can, try to sit near that wall with all the framed signed photos of 80s celebs. I think we spotted Bobby McFerrin up there.
author: Macheeks ..

description: pasta is best in all san fran... every time we visit we come here!
author: Daina M.

description:
another dissenting voice.  Just didn't think it lives up to all the rave reviews on here.  The service was friendly and it is a cozy little place (but for the photo of Pete Rose that was staring at us upstairs), but I thought the food was a bit too heavy and greasy.

The caprese salad was pretty good and the tiramisu was homemade and excellent.  But the other dishes we ordered were disappointing.  The menu is very meat-centric (NOT vegetarian friendly).   I ordered the eggplant pasta, which was swimming in oil.  I tasted the gnocchi which was in a cream sauce and it was bland yet very very heavy.
author: mazzy r.

description:
It's hard to find bad Italian food in North Beach...so many places to choose from. But that doesn't mean it's easy to find exceptional Italian food there. North Beach is SF's Little Italy, and pretty much every Italian place, at the very least, fits into the "doesn't suck" class. 

But Contadina's in a class by itself. I eat there every time I'm in the city (like ~6 times a year), and I've never had a bad meal yet. 

It's more of a locals joint, and even though it's right on the streetcar line, I rarely see a lot of tourists eating there. But that's fine...that means it'll stay cool. 

But it doesn't mean it's empty. Show up after six and you'll wait. Show up after seven with no reservation, and you won't even get to eat at the bar. This place is packed until after ten. 

But if you're in North Beach and you want Italian, you owe it to yourself to go here just once.
author: Daniel K.

description: Easily the best italian in town!  Everything I've ever had here has been spectacular.  Super fresh ingredients plus great wine selection.  Highly recommend any dish with their tomato cream sauce.  Absolutely love it.
author: Aldo K.

description:
Trattoria Contadina is an outstanding restaurant with tasty food, affordable prices, great service, and delightful ambiance.

I dined at Contadina with 2 friends on a Thursday night.  It's a small restaurant, but we were able to get a reservation at 8PM with only short notice.  The restaurant is conveniently located on Union and Mason, and easily accessible by Muni (45 line goes up and down Union and stops right by the front door in both directions).

The gnocchi was hearty, flavorful, and served in a perfect sized portion for me.  Those looking for a little less food also have the option of a smaller, half-size order.  The classic Cesar salad and bread with olive oil were also delicious.

Trattoria is a nice restaurant, with a casual elegant interior.  I like it because you can fit in wearing a suit or a t-shirt, and everything in between.  

I don't have a lot of experience with North Beach Italian restaurants, so I can't compare too much.  That said, I highly recommend Trattoria Contadina for delicious Italian food and a enjoyable experience.
author: Aaron R.

description:
Great Southern Italian food. 

Big fan of the eggplant and pepper starters.  Pastas are much better here than entrees.    Atmosphere is cozy but tables are too close together - expect to be bumped a few times by the efficient/friendly service.
author: Stacy N.

description: Had a wonderful trip to the City over the weekend and Trattoria Contadina was spot on in all aspects. Very pleasant folks, seated at my reservation time (8:30) and the food was great! My daughter had Boco Chicken special. I wanted something a bit more exciting than chicken and had Saltimbocca. Saltimbocca was wonderful but I have to admit, my daughter's Boco Chicken was beyond my vocabulary to describe the taste bud experience for chicken! Go. You won't be disappointed and I will, definately, be back. (Oh, of course, Tiramisu for desert - yum)
author: David S.

description: Best brunch!! This favorite of ours now serves brunch on the weekends.  Don't miss it! They take reservations and the food is varied, delicious and very reasonably priced.  Try Mama Correnti's Zucchini Bread, the pasta of the day, ricotta cheese pancakes and poached eggs!  Our group has wild dietary restrictions (no dairy, vegan, no red meats, blah, blah) and everyone found a delicious entree and raved about it!  Don't walk, RUN to Trattoria for brunch!
author: A O.

description: What a wonderful find in North Beach off the beaten path. Well worth finding. Make reservations. The host was great. The Carlesimo dish was AMAZING!!!!! Love thier pink sauce. Will definately go again.
author: Suzy m.

description: Really loved this place. We were late for our reservation because of taxi issues and they were super understanding when we called. It's a pretty intimate atmosphere (read: not a ton of room between tables) but the wait stuff was polite and helpful and the food was delicious. Will definitely be going back.
author: Alexandra B.

description:
I really was surprised how much I liked this place.  Really relaxed, unhurried Italian.  Some of the North Beach favourites can get a bit 'hasty' but these guys know how to keep the dinner moving without making you feel rushed.

Very fresh pasta dishes.  I had linguini with meatballs - which were delicious, freshly cooked, and served with pomodoro sauce with fresh basil.  Parmesan on top was grated on fresh from a LARGE block. Mmmmmm.  My wife had the stuffed veal.  Really good, and fresh again.  Maybe a few too many flavours on one plate - marsala wine sauce, sage stuffing, mozzarella, and pomodoro sauce served with garlic mash  - but that seems the SF way... most restaurants here seem to like mixing too many flavours.

But - all in - a very pleasant experience.  Good for mid-week italian.  I will be back.
author: Michael R.

description: I absolutely love this place. I have been going here for over 10 years now, and have never left disappointed. I always leave with a full stomach and lots of smiles. The restaurant is cozy and cute, the service is great, and the food is to die for. I usually get the raviolis - they haven't failed me yet. Give it try if you haven't been. It doesn't get more San Francisco than this place.
author: John G.

description:
The Bell Pepper is stupid. I mean i cant get enough. App Main Course Dessert. Large portions. The Lil espresso drink at the end. The best thing is the people who work there have been there a while. I don't know his name but when pop is behind the counter in the kitchen its hot and good. Not to take any thing away from the servers but i think the timing comes from him. He gives you a minute to digest that Rich app. The timing is phenomenal. I once saw Adam Sandler here. The Cable Car past him and his then pregnant wife right by. Nice guy i silently saluted him and he was very gracious in his salute back. 

I will be coming here forever.
author: rich s.

description:
My boyfriend went here on a Monday and were seated immediately, though it did get pretty full throughout our meal.  Didn't appear anyone waited too long and they were kindly greeted by Milo, the host, who graciously took care of everyone while remembering names and conversations at each table.  

Wine list is not too overwhelming but epitomizes quality over quantity.  I went in really wanting to try the raved about tomato cream sauce and as most always, yelpers did not disappoint.  We started with a small order (which is plenty as a full course) of the gnocchi which we were told actually doesn't have potato in it, but ricotta cheese.  Followed the gnocchi with the salvatore (?) chicken ravioli which were just as good as described from prior yelpers.  My boyfriend ordered the chicken with smoked mozzarella, garlic mashed potatoes and spinach.  I can speak to the chicken as it was tender and the mashed potatoes were great as well.  We finished up with a chocolate torta with an espresso cookie which was equally as great as the ambiance, service and rest of the meal.  

As a San Franciscan it was also nice that it was a bit off the beaten path and not in the strip of other authentic Italian restaurants that seem to overwhelm each other.  

Definitely worthy trying, you won't be disappointed!!
author: Erin C.

description:
The food and atmosphere here was great.  It was definitely cramped which bothered some people in my party but not me - I like the intimacy of it (and it makes it feel more like you're really somewhere in Italy).  But I have to stay the service was definitely lacking at the beginning of the meal.  We waited for probably 30 minutes before anyone came to our table to ask if we'd like drinks.  Also, I was asking the waiter for wine recommendations and he seemed to have no idea what he was talking about.  

I definitely recommend the caesar salad (yum!) and the linguini and meatballs.  Most everyone at our table liked their dishes a lot.  Our biggest complaint was that the secondi menu consisted mostly of veal or chicken dishes.  A lot of people don't eat veal and I refuse to order chicken in a restaurant because I'm convinced I can do it just as well at home.
author: Julia J.

description: Excellent Italian food. I really enjoyed their cheese ravioli. The ambiance feels a little cramped, but fun.
author: A C.

description:
Get the gnocchi as an appetizer to share. It's way too rick for one person to eat on their own, but shared as an app among a few - you'll get the full benefit of enjoying this amazing dish and still have room for other things.

My husband and I love this place. If it weren't so darn cute and charming and old world inside, I'm not sure if we'd love it AS much because there may in fact be better Italian elsewhere (hence the 4 stars and not 5).
