But the service is always good at TC, and as other Yelpers have said - this place is the real deal, a glimpse at what SF's food "scene" probably was 50 or 60 years ago. I also cannot stand Delfina and don't see what the fuss is about. And I also admittedly enjoy Olive Garden. So if you're Delfina lovers and/or Olive Garden haters, TC may not be for you. 

It's the one date night place my husband and I will go into the city for, and we both lived in SF for over a decade. 

and if they ever have the calamari steak as a daily special (I can't seem to ever time my visits right to get it) - GET IT. It is insanely awesome.
author: Minkey L.

description:
Can't go wrong coming here and this was my first, so be gentle.  We had an option to sit near the door, but who would ever want to do that?  Wind? People walking by? So off to the second level.  It reminded me of my family's family room.  

I sat down and immediately started leaning to my left. Why you ask?  The floor is quite level, that is a bit of an understatement.  Regardless of the new look on life it took a little bit to order as there was only one server and one bus boy who was on the ball about bread.  I really do wish they had parm for the olive oil.

The linguine with clams was a bit too much on the lemon and made it difficult to taste the other flavors.  The pasta was cooked well the clams were tasty.  The other dish was a ravioli which was good.  I forgot what it was.

This is off the beaten path of Italian restaurants in N. Beach.  A good place to have dinner with friends or even a date.  If you you've everywhere else then climb up to here, It's on a small hill.
author: Po L.

description:
I'm not usually a big Italian restaurant fan, but I have to say I was impressed with this place!  

This was a very quaint, pleasant restaurant.  Our waiter was excellent providing suggestions that our party was pleased with.  He was confident in the menu and his advice and I was satisfied.  I had the Ravioli all Salvatore and it was DELICIOUS!  

It felt like a hidden gem!!  I will be bringing my parents here on their next SF visit!!
author: Beth R.

description: This place was awesome. Nice, fast, and tasty! Cant wait to go back. My BF and I went for his Birthday. Salads and dinner in 30min.. OMG!. With the extra time we got to take in the scenery.
author: Kimberly P.

description: Best Italian in North Beach.  There, I said it.  Charming, right off the Mason/Powell cable car line.  Always packed - mostly of locals who know it is the best Italian in North Beach.  I used to live down the street and made it a point to visit at least once a month for various pasta and piatti secondi.  Great for a date or a smaller group - impressed my now-wife with this place, also had a couple of birthdays here.  It's worth a visit.
author: Todd S.

description: We absolutely loved all of our meals.  The service was fantastic and we loved the ambiance as well.  It was nice to be out of the tourist trap type of restaurant and this placed seemed like we were walking into someone's family home.  We can not wait to go back on our next visit to the city!
author: Annie F.

description: I liked that this restaurant was away from the hustle and bustle of North Beach. It felt for neighborhood-y. Good for an intimate dinner with friends/significant others.  Wine selection for an Italian restaurant was terrible though. Loved the dried figs in the Insalata Rucola. The chicken raviola was good too, if you want something creamy and satisfying that way. The Fruitti de Mare was a little too butter-y for my taste.  If you have space for dessert, definitely try the Torta di Cioccolato (but split it because it's huge!)
author: Ayesha B.

description: Intimate neighborhood place a block off Columbus,  run in the family tradition.  The owner and his staff are very pleasant and attentive.  Everyone in our party enjoyed their food immensely...portions are large and the prices are very fair.  We will be back for more yummy food.
author: John K.

description: I love this place. It is relatively small, warm - feels almost like home (if home had amazing pasta). The service is great. I've tried several pasta dishes and never been disappointed. It has legions of fans - and deserves them all.
author: Colleen Z.

description: I can't speak to traditional Italian meals or authentic sauces or the right ingredients.  I can say that Trattoria Contadina gets five stars in my book for its off the beaten path-location, solid atmosphere, attentive and polite service, and delicious food.  Even on a busy Valentine's Day, the restaurant remained relaxed and romantic (alliteration is always the sign of a strong dining experience).  Certainly one of my favorite Italian places in the City and definitely a spot I will revisit several times over.
author: P D.

description:
Great food and wine, wonderful for groups. Very diverse selection and attentive wait staff.

This is the place for you.
author: Sean K.

description:
Order the Ravioli Salvatori, and prepare for the beginning of an addiction.  Trattoria Contadina is up the street from my house, and I go there regularly. The decor is nothing to write home about but the pasta is fantastic.  The Ravioli Salvatore is the most incredible pasta dish I've ever had....  Rosemary and sundried tomatoes in a lovely creamy chicken sauce. Sounds odd - tastes wonderful.  The Carlisimo is great as well - huge portions and very flavorful.  If you like spaghetti and meatballs, Contadina's will be one of the best you've ever had.

The service is fast and good every time I go.  My favorite waiter is Milo, who while hilarious, isn't at all overbearing and is both friendly and efficient.  I also like that it's a little off the beaten path, so you don't see a ton of tourists, like the rest of North Beach.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I live a block up the street from this place. 
It is hands down one of the top Italian restaurants in North Beach. 
I highly recommend the clam linguine. Amazing. Other than that you really can't go wrong. They don't get the foot traffic like the restaurants on columbus, but they are always full. Reservations are needed especially on the weekend.  It is definitely warm in there so if you are on a date, don't wear a wool sweater unless you want to sweat profusely. (never a good thing)
author: Brandon B.

description:
I moved to North Beach from the Mission (oh do I miss the amazing restaurants there!) but was pleasantly surprised to find this treasure down the block from my new digs. 

Small, charming, warm (literally if you sit upstairs above the kitchen - I started sweating!) and delicious. The tortellini is filling and tasty. Affordable and authentic Italian in my new hood. Love it!
author: Carin B.

description: Love. Best Italian in North Beach. The Roasted Pepper appetizer is one of my favorite dishes in the city. As far a pasta goes, you can not go wrong with the Beef Tortellini or Salvatore. Secondi dishes are amazing as well. I recently found out that they started doing brunch.. This is a must try!
author: Rachel S.

description: Was in San Francisco this past weekend with my fiance and we were looking for some great Italian food for our last night in town (Sunday) This place is off the beaten path a bit, just outside the strip of North Beach with all the restaurants, which we like.... we may be tourists, but we don't want a tourist trap.  We got a cute table upstairs by the window and had an amazing waiter.  He was quick to recommend some wine for us and actually brought us a bottle that isn't even on their menu (it was great by the way) The food was amazing and not too expensive.  This was exactly what we wanted for our last night in town.  Can't wait until we are up north again.  We will be back!
author: Kelly C.

description: Has become my favorite neighborhood restaurant. Their risotto is sooooo yummy. Service is great. Just a bit noisy, but not bad. The ambience is wonderful. I also love the little bar that is available.
author: Pamela B.

description: We were in San Francisco for the weekend and my friend who lives there recommended this place. IT WAS AWESOME! A very nice couple owns this place and it shows. Everyone was very nice, the food was wonderful, and very reasonably priced considering San Francisco prices. Good wine values too! If you want Italian go here.
author: Isaac A.

description: My partner and I started coming to Trattoria Contadina before we even lived in SF, and we have been coming here ever since. We love this place, the owners (Dirk. now Gina and Kevin) have always been so wonderful. We loved this place so much we even had our wedding reception here.  This place is so great, laid back, great service, and so typical of a neighborhood SF restaurant. Tourists come here and I am sure they leave with a good taste in their mouths.. both for the food and the SF hospitality. The only reason I don't give them 5 stars, is the fact I live in another part of the city and can't walk here for a meal!
author: Alan F.

description: It's great to find more of a local Italian restaurant outside the jaws of the toursity North Beach strip on Columbus. We had a party of 5 and were instantly in love with the appetizer Pepperoni Arrostiti con Formaggio, which was roasted yellow bell peppers and scrumptious cheeses that compliment quite nicely. The pastas and entrees were delicious. We had heard prior to going that the tomato sauce was a bit bland, and it was, however, the other white sauces on the dishes were tantalizing for our tastebuds. It definitely rocks to sit upstairs and the service is quick, attentive, and comprehensive. Bravo!
author: Braden B.

description: Very good-one of the best salads I have ever had w/Beets,pistachios and a very tasty pasta that had some delicious beef infused "sauce" I like that you can get either the smaller portion or larger,I was happy w/smaller one especially if you have an appetizer before.Excellent service,waiter was very pleasant and Nicole the hostess is great!!
author: james m.

description: Went here last Saturday with BF and friends from out of town....it was very yum!  BF and I both had veal dishes and friends had a seafood pasta...will definitely come again
author: Letty B.

description:
This has long been one of my favorite spots in north beach - very good pasta, friendly staff and nice warm atmosphere. They have one pasta dish that keeps us going back there, it's a corkscrew pasta with chicken, veggies and an amazing white cream sauce. i don't know what they put in the sauce but it is truly addicting.  Their prices are reasonable and the little bar has a good selection.  They lost one star based on the fact that they are now so popular that you always need reservations - annoying. I once went in there alone at 5pm on a Monday... and they said that they could not serve me, i needed a reservation - What? for one? on monday? at 5pm?  crazy. I ended up eating at the bar which was fine with me.  
overall, the food makes this little place worth it. it's delicious. just be sure to make reservations - they are on opentable.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
This has got to be my all time favorite restaurant ever. The hostess (who I now believe, is either related to the family, or is a part owner herself) was extremely friendly and by the end of our amazing meal she had gifted me brand new cookbook with recipes from some of the best Italian restaurants in the country. I am absolutely in love with Trattoria Contadina and although I live on the east coast I will make a special trip back to San Fran again just for the great food and atmosphere.

Service was also excellent. 5 stars!!
author: Katelin G.

description: Went here for dinner with about 10 people from work on 3/30.  Food was fantastic!  Will definitely be back with my wife.
author: Mike O.

description: Very San Francisco Italian...excellent food in a friendly atmosphere..nice service...we will definitely go back...Norm and Sue from Castro Valley, Ca.
author: Norman B.

description:
I'd heard someone say Trattoria Contadina was the best Italian restaurant they'd been to in San Francisco.  I wondered then if they'd ever been to Italy.  I can now say, definitively, they have not!

If your experience with Italian food ends with Chef Boyardee, this place won't disappoint.  If you know what Italian food CAN taste like, this place will disappoint and disappoint sorely.

Our table had the radicchio salad, the spaghetti vongole, the pasta fresca, and the saltimboca.  The salad was good.  Nothing else was.

Oh, and the wine mark-up is 500%.  Really?  At that rate, I can go to Italy and get my own for less.
We all left feeling ill as though an entire bulb of garlic was lodged in our throat and nothing except the passage of time could cure it.
author: Drexel B.

description: Solid Italian food. Generally I prefer the type of Italian food at Vicolleto's, slightly lighter and fresher tasting (unfortunately also more expensive). But sometimes, I crave good ole'fashioned hearty Italian food and Trattoria Contadina hits the spot. Everything I have had is tasty. Last night I had the spinach salad and Salvatore pasta, both did not disappoint. Overall: reasonably priced, friendly service, and comfortable ambiance.
author: Rose K.

description: This is a lovely, cozy little restaurant...just my style! We arrived at this place on a fluke just walking around on a Sunday night looking for somewhere to eat without a long wait. We didn't have reservations but got a table within 20 minutes flat, since it was just 2 of us we were able to sit at the bar and have drink while waiting. It was late and I was starving! I had the Pavarotti, delicious fusilli pasta with sautéed chicken, prosciutto, zucchini, sun-dried tomatoes and a cream sauce....per the waitress suggestion. I will definitely return to this place!
author: Leslie A.

description: LOVE this place!!!! By far my favorite Italian restaurant in Bay area if not my favorite overall.  This little place is what I would fondly call a little hole in the wall (term of endearment in the south) ... One of those small places you love and hope the crowds don't find out about.....unfortunately I think they already have!!  The gnocchi with pink cream sauce......is a must!!!!  I love that they offer different portion sizes of their dishes. Service is always wonderful.  While it is a "come as you are place" I would make a reservation just to make sure you get a table.
author: Susan T.

description: This place is definitely one of the better Italian restaurants around North Beach. It's a small cozy little place that can get really crowded so be sure to make reservations. Tables are set closely to each other so don't expect much privacy. The food is excellent though! I always get the bruschetta to start off. It only comes out with two pieces of bread so be sure to have more than one order if you have more people. Bruschetta is a pretty simple dish, but the perfectly toasted slice of bread that it comes with had just enough EVOO and the tomatoes were seasoned very well. 2 slices of Bruschetta = $7.00. Expensive, but worth it. The fresh clams and muscles steamed in white wine sauce is also another one of my favorites. The server once suggested that we get the Pepperoni Arrostiti, which was a plate of bell peppers stopped with lots of cheese. I didn't like it at all. Their entrees come in half and full size orders, which I love. I really enjoyed the Fusilli pasta with sautéed chicken, prosciutto, zucchini, and sun-dried tomatoes. I've been here a few times and always left feeling full and satisfied. What I love best about this place is the coziness of the restaurant: dim lighting, candlelit tables, and the interior set up of the restaurant made it seem like I was eating in my own dining room. Two thumbs up for friendly and efficient service =)
author: Lynn V.

description: Molto bene!!! Grew up in Northbeach and have eaten at places like this since I was a kid.  I found it perfectly homey, the food authentic and the service pleasant and welcoming.  Just like Grandma used to make!
author: Angela L.

description: Been here a while ago. My wine glass was half full and the radicchio was single-leafed, but I gotta say, the waiter really came through. I rarely say this - the food was so-so, but the service was really su-per, not pretentious or anything. Just straightforward, humorous and nice.
author: Dr K.

description: Almost don't want to write this review because I love this place so much and don't want it to get even more popular. AWESOME fresh food, interesting menu, and just a really cozy atmosphere that keeps me coming back every chance I get.
author: Meg M.

description:
service was horrible. 

took forever to get a check, took forever to get the food, they don't accept amex, felt cramped eating dinner- too bad they didn't know we just bought a place nearby and it could have been our go to neighborhood restaurant. 

never again. 

(food = unmemorable, nothing was decent enough for me to disassociate the food from the experience)
author: Hannah W.

description: Doesn't everyone in SF know about this place by now? This was my go-to restaurant for great Italian food for 10 years. Living so close to North Beach I was able to try all of them, yet TC kept me coming back for more. My favorites are the Fusilli Pavarotti and the Frutti di Mare.  And their gnocchi is some of the best I've ever had. The service is always good no matter how busy they get. With that said, make reservations if you're eating here over the weekend.  I've never met anyone who did not have a great dining experience here. I'm missing you, TC!
author: Aimee G.

description: What a lovely setting, just a block off Columbus on a quiet corner. Charming, family run Italian restaurant, with a great menu selection, wonderful owner and staff, fast service, excellent food, and inexpensive. The staff was kind enough to split our bill several ways, so everyone could get reimbursed. An new favorite place to eat.
author: Kathy i.

description: I see this place everyday on my way to work ... the 41 takes you right by it. And it's as if it was Groundhog Day, cause I'm glued to the window every time, like, "Ooo yeah. We need to go there soon for dinner." Being of Italian blood, I tend to attract these places by instinct. I just happen upon them, like I did with this place a few years ago, and well, I am sure glad I did. Trattoria Contadina is like family to me ... it seats you close to your neighbor (so prepare to get cozy) and the portions are rather healthy (just like mom use to make). The carb diet is not allowed here, unless you want to embarrass yourself. The more the better, so eat up!
author: Amanda C.

description: This is a 2.5 star restaurant.  The people here are nice and the atmosphere is cozy.  The food is just North Beach average.  No different than what you'll find in the 50 other Italian restaurants in the area.
author: John N.

description: Pretty good, a little off the beaten Columbus Avenue path, but worth the diversion.  Pasta was good... had the Gnocchi alla Napolentana.  Sat in a little loft up above the main dining room.  Staff seemed fairly friendly.  Feels more like a neighborhood joint rather than a tourist trap.  Will probably come back.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Cozy traditional Italian. A little pricey. Great service.  Great food.
author: Scott M.

description:
Given my exceptional skill in meatball-making, I am often tempted to try meatballs where ever I go to see just how much better my cooking is. Having been burned too many times, I've limited myself only to higher-end restaurants where there's a lower risk of the balls being god-awful. I am so sad to report that this place had god-awful meatballs and god-awful marinara and spaghetti to accompany. 

What gives? I thought this would be a slam dunk based on Yelp reviews. Boyfriend's family in town, nice cozy restaurant watching the cable cars pass just out the window after a long day of walking and sight-seeing. 

I played it off when the waiter didn't understand what was meant by "fettuccine alfredo" when my boyfriend's cheese-loving brother asked. It's cool, it's cool. My turn. I ask if they could make the polenta and mushroom appetizer without the shrimp (allergy). He goes to the back to ask and says yes, but since the sauce is premade, I'll have to have a different sauce. I ask to let the chef recommend something (another mushroom sauce that's in other dishes on the menu) which results in this man's blank page stare becoming even blanker. 

They brought out unbaked polenta (with no sign of a mushroom) swimming in Ragu. Horrifyingly disgusting. I asked what happened to the mushrooms. He explained that they were in the pre-made sauce and so they swapped it with marinara. You can imagine the lovely thoughts I'm having about which small-brained animals must work in the back. The bruschetta was a knock-out, so I remained optimistic that my secret meatball challenge at the main course could still be a success. 

The garlic and three-cheese pasta my boyfriend had tasted like Easy Mac and the excessive amoung of oil had pooled. The mushroom gnocchi his mom got was exceptional. The fettuccine alfredo is better at Olive Garden. My meatballs were personally offensive. My boyfriend's family owns and runs a restaurant and bar that serves meatballs. I first tasted naked meat ball sans sauce. I shook my head, certain I could have gotten a better meat concoction from a can. After the face I made at the rancidity of the marinara in the next bite, everyone insisted on trying it -- could it be *that* bad? Not only was it bad, but my bf, his mom and brother,  chefs and long-time patrons at their own family restaurant all agreed that they were restaurant supply meatballs that all bar-food places buy frozen. "They're unmistakable," were her words. This would be cool if I were at a bar, drunk, paying bar-food prices, expecting in my intoxicated state that the frozen meatballs would be delicious. Not cool, Trattoria Contadina. 

The tiramisu looked as though it was thrown frisbee-style onto the plate. It tasted better than Sara Lee, but it was nearly splattered. Nice. 

Great. Thanks. At least I know the unmistakable taste of frozen Restaurant Supply brand meatballs now. Suck.
author: Remy O.

description: this is a very cute italian restaurant away from the chaos on Columbus that i will definitely come to again. we sat upstairs giving us a quite private meal with very attentive and friendly service. The wine was pricey if you just want 1 glass ($9 cheapest for a glass of red) and the specialties were over $20 but if you come for lunch or a light dinner their pasta dishes are very reasonable and delicious. The meatball linguine was great and enough for 2 girls and the ravioli looked amazing, i will try that next time. a friend who heard i went told me next time i go i would be crazy not to get their stuffed bell peppers.
author: Barbara C.

description: I have walked by this place a million times and finally went there this past weekend. It was definitely as great as I thought it would be. I have never ever seen this place not full but they were able to seat me and my friend right away (thank goodness for reservations). Everything from the wine to the salad to my pasta entree was delicious! The prices are spot on and I love that they offer have portions. Oh, and this may be a little thing, but they are great about keeping your water full and that is a big plus for me. In short, this is a fantastic North Beach Italian restaurant that is away from the nonstop crazy touristy Columbus street.
author: Kate J.

description: The location was perfect for dinner before Beach Blanket Babylon but the food was only okay.  The carrot soup was too creamy, frutta di mare spaghetti was okay - pasta was nothing special.  The best part of the meal was the side of garlic broccolini (it came with the entrees that night) - absolutely perfectly done and very tasty.
author: P L.

description: YUM.  This was my first time here and I ordered the beef ravioli with tomato cream sauce... and let me tell you, I licked my plate clean!  It's a quaint little restaurant and gets extremely busy.  I would recommend making reservations.  I ate there on a Sunday night and we had to wait 45 minutes.  I would definitely go back to try other dishes.
author: Jules M.

description: I recommend the blackberry cabernet sorbet for dessert if you save room.  The Salvatore (chicken ravioli) was okay, sauce was the stand-out part and I felt there were too few ravioli's in my dish; at least in comparison to the portions of Polpettine (spaghetti w/ meatballs) or the Pavarotti (pasta w/ cream sauce, zucchini and chicken).
author: Jenn W.

description: Standard Italian fare in North Beach.  My capellini was a little bland and the radicchio salad quite average.  It definitely has a very traditional, family owned Italian feel to it.  I'll stop by again to try some of the other dishes, but for now 3 stars.
author: Mamoon H.

description:
I walked in with two girlfriends on a bustling Sat. night, when the rest of the North Beach restaurants we wanted to go to were full. My friend Susan addressed the hostess by her first name and within minutes we were led to a table upstairs. Our table was dangerously situated on a slant, but we decided a nice bottle wine would fix that situation, at least mentally we would think we were sitting on flat ground. From the outside, I always thought Contadina was really fancy, but sitting down amongst our fellow diners, I realized that it was really just homey with old Italian charm (you know, black and white photos of random famous people who've dinner there over the years). We were surrounded by tables of happy, boisterous families, which set the mood for a relaxed, unpretentious evening. I ordered a chicken and cheese ravioli in a creme sauce with sun dried tomatoes. When our food arrived, my plate lacked any hint of warmth. I looked across the table at my friend Danielle's plate of pesto, which was billowing steam off the top. I took one bite of a ravioli and decided to flag down the waiter. I really hate doing this, especially when the waitstaff is so sweet, which they were, but I didn't exactly want to eat a cold meal. He was great about it. He whisked my dish away and apologized, "I'm sorry, we don't have heat lamps here," which usually means the food is really fresh and ready to go the minute it hits the plate. But unfortunately mine had been sitting for a while waiting for it's good friend pesto pasta to be done. He reappeared with my plate within minutes. The food was tasty and hot, and was accompanied by a lovely bottle of Barbaresco. It really wasn't my favorite meal ever, but I know this place could do better. I'm determine to come back and order a real winner. Suzy had a delicious meal of twisty pasta with scallops in this creamy sauce. She has been telling me about this restaurant for two years and she finally took me and felt kind of bad that my meal wasn't all she hoped it would be. So for her, I will go back and will learn to love it!

****Update*****

I went back last night and was treated to a steaming bowl of pesto linguine! It was absolutely delicious. This is a solid dining experience. The only problem is trying to flag down the servers to get the bill (oh, and the crying baby next to us. I'm working on liking the babies more, but when they're screaming next to your bowl of pasta it's hard to considerer them cute).
author: Sammy S.

description:
since my days of living in north beach, i don't get here that much anymore.  i used to live really close to this place and walk to work in the morning (15 minutes) and walk home from the financial district at night.  how cool was that?  except that living in North Beach is so ridiculously over-rated it's not even funny.  one time, this go-go dancer girl that i knew called me at 2am to come get her from her gig becuase she "drank too much'...  anyway, it was .75 miles and 2am at night but it took me like 30 minutes!!!  why?  because it doesn't matter what time it is, there's 30 minutes of traffic in north beach!!!!  2am... noon... weekday... weekend... there are so many people every where, it's too damn much traffic.  tourists and bridge+tunnel people EVERYWHERE!  but i digress.  

my point is that i used to live in north beach and - take it from someone that used to live there - this was one of the BEST italian restaurants there. i have some friends that still live in north beach - despite the traffic and the poor location relative to the rest of the city - and when i visit them, we often come here for dinner.  food is amazing and as classic italian as you can get.  the caprese salad is fresh, the veal is thinly sliced and whatever you get on top (i usually get the marsala sauce) is excellent.  not too salty or too creamy.  the pasta is "al dente" (google it).  the light dishes are pretty light and the fish dishes are medium while the heavier dishes are not over-stuffed with meat and fat.  

on the wine list, try the amarone if you haven't had it.  they pull the grapes off the vine and let them dry in the sun.  since they are dried out a litte bit, it concentrates the juice and the wine is very dense and strong. the Cesare is one of the best and most affordable amarone's you're going to find.  normally, you can't get an amarone less than $100, but i think they have it on the list for $70.  

the handmade tiramisu is claimed to be the best in SF.  i can't argue. the only issues are that you should really get a reservation.  we came on an off-night and they only had one table left by the front.  i didn't think we'd need reservations but in the future, it doesn't matter what day i come, i'm going to reserve.
author: dan h.

description: I love Trattoria Contadina !  When I lived in SF I ate there, when I visit SF I eat there.   It's always good, and smells fantastic.   I totally disagree that it's not a good place for kids, we bring our kids there and they make them whatever they want even if it's not on the menu.   If you make reservations you'll be sure to have a great time.   If you try to walk in, it can get tiring waiting outside.
author: Chris P.

description: This little Italian cozy restaurant was superb!!!!! It's located on a residential corner in north beach, which makes it more quiet but very San Franciscan at the same time. The Cable Car takes you right to the door of the restaurant, so if you have friends in town you can maximize the experience! Ok for the food.....it was very good! Everything had rich flavors and ingredients making the dishes seem ultra savory. Staff was incredibly friendly and the overall atmosphere was very chill. A very good date spot! not so much for big groups. Tables were mostly for two people and very close together. The reason for four stars is mainly due to the desert, which tasted very average. Maybe it was what we had ordered....Bottom line: I would definitely go back, I would just order another desert.
author: Niki F.

description: We ended a day trip to San Fran here and it was such a great cap to the day. I got the clam pasta which was very, very good. Everyone at our table loved their dishes! The interior was very cozy (but not cramped) and had a good home-y feel.
author: Grace L.

description:
Good place.  I have tried to get in here for a long time but the lack of parking has always dissuaded me.  Finally took the time to do it and am glad I did.

Small restaurant with spice.

Waitstaff friendly and knowledgeable about the menu.  

Food was solid.  Portions large.  Prices reasonable.  Desserts good.  

Best thing:  no tourists.  :)
author: Karen B.

description: Good food, good service, good atmosphere.  Nothing not to like here.  Gets only four stars because the food, while good, was nothing remarkable.
author: Anonymous P.

description: I've lived in the neighborhood for 3 years. THIS PLACE IS THE BEST ITALIAN IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD. Stay away from Columbus and walk up the hill.. be sure  to have a reservation.
author: Chris N.

description: Go here for great service, delicious AUTHENTIC Italian cuisine (Although I am Pizza's #1 fan, I'm kind of intrigued by its absence here), and a wonderful dining experience for a reasonable price! A cozy little loper with limited seating (make reservations, friends).
author: Scott G.

description: I really like this place.  It has a homey feel and even though you get a lot of tourists, it still has a local vibe.  The food is really very good, generous portions and reasonably priced and you can't beat the atmosphere right off the cable car line (tip - dont get put up in the second floor back room)!!  I'm not an italian food expert, but I know what I like, and I will definitely be coming bavck! (Try the Tiramisu, too!)
author: Emma L.

description: Try the cheese stuffed bell pepper appetizer.  Not light--but amazing...  Friendly staff, very tasty food, and well priced.  A bit off the beaten path, making it a terrific choice for local Italian.
author: E P.

description: 2 WORDS: BAD EXPERIENCE!!!!!!!!! I would give this ZERO stars, but Yelp won't let me... Went to this restaurant this past weekend with my husband- party of 2. Never been there before, live in the neighborhood, and wanted to try it. Made reservations and got there on time- seated, and then WAITED FOR 25 MINUTES for the WAITER TO EVEN NOTICE US- LET ALONE COME TO OUR TABLE! I thought it was a joke... I gave it one more minute, and then I got up and asked the lady (politely) at the front who was seating people- where is the manager? She said she WAS the manager- I said "25 minutes.. we were sitting there for 25 minutes..." no waiter, no wine, no attention, nothing.. ridiculous.  I am very disappointed and even if the food is supposedly tasty- I AM NEVER GOING BACK because service is just as important when you are looking for a nice dining experience.  Instead, we walked down the street to Caffe De Lucchi, http://www.caffedelucchi.com seated immediately, and not only experienced immediate and impressive service- we had a fantastic  meal and overall experience. I do not typically write negative reviews- but this one left a bad TASTE in my mouth, so to speak.
author: nikky d.

description:
Sunday.
6 of us get together for dinner.
As always, parking in SF is shit.
We're about 5 minutes late of our reservation.
We walk in.
Crowded. Small. Cozy. Smells great.
Find our table. Order drinks.
Stolli Martini, clean. Huckkk!!! This sucker was more like a vodka and  an olive! Dang.
Our server is really nice and attentive and gets us settled in.
We ask about a few of the wines. I get a feeling she know only so much. Oh, well.
My friend decided on the 2002  Cabernet Sauvignon, Mario Perelli-Minetti, Napa Valley.
Carpaccio di Manzo.
Thinly sliced raw Filet Mignon with fresh arugula, parmesan cheese, extra virgin olive oil and capers.
Too much capers. Needed more parmesan. Otherwise, pretty good.
Insalata alla Casare
Fresh hearts of romaine, classic Caesar dressing, parmesan cheese and garlic croutons.
Really, really good. I'm a snob when it comes to Caesar salads. Especially the dressing. 
Costolette di Vitello alla Rustica
Grilled veal chop with a balsamic vinegar reduction, red onion and capers sauce, served with fresh sauted garlic spinach and creamy soft polenta.
Again, too much capers. The reduction could have been reduced a lot more. But still, it was very tasty.
Homemade Tiramisu.
Rum and espresso soaked lady fingers, Layered with mascarpone cheese.
Mmmm.........
Torta di Cioccolato
Chocolate cappuccino mousse cake served with raspberry sauce 
Agh............
Pricy, but very well worth it.
author: Kione E.

description: Just steps away from the tourist chaos ... there is a haven of amazing Italian food at reasonable prices.  This place really delivers.  The atmosphere is simple, if not a bit crowded, but the food is amazing.  The pasta is so soft it melts in your mouth.  You can tell it is homemade fresh  in house each day.  I had a fantastic arugula salad with beets and goat cheese and the pasta with panchetta and sun dried tomatoes.  Both were among the best Italian food in SF.  I Highly recommend this place...but make a reservation.  They do get pretty busy!
author: David A.

description: Amidst a sea of gimmicky tourist-oriented places in North Beach, Trattoria Contadina is a slice of old school San Francisco, with a great atmosphere and personable service.  I can't quite give it 5 stars, as the food itself, while memorable and very good, is not quite at the fantastic level, but this is a great option for traditional Italian food.
author: Ty D.

description: so yummy - I had the gnocci there on saturday night and was really amazed! the ravioli alle salvatore was also really good. The prices were definitely affordable and I intend to add this to my takeout list. Though i wasn't overly excited by the lemon cheesecake.. might want to pick up dessert from swenson's..
author: Heidi L.

description: Went there on a Sunday night.  Everything was perfect, including the girl who took our reservations over the phone.  The atmosphere and look of the place reminds me of Frascati.   It was such a cute place!   I ordered the polenta with mushrooms and the rigatoni for an entree.  All sooo delicious.  Homemade pasta really does taste different than the stuff you buy from Safeway.  The pasta was chewy and the sauce was perfect.  The portions were huge!  I'll definitely go back.  There's just so much on the menu I want to try!
author: Helen C.

description: Go back every time we are in San Francisco, wonderful restaurant. Very cute little place with wonderful food. We made our reservation on opentable and had no problem. Service was very good. As an appetizer we had the eggplant, which is delicious. We have tried several of the pastas and they are all good.
author: Natalie V.

description: Large portions. Large crowds. Noisy. Energetic Staff. Simply amazing Italian Food!!!!
author: Prescott T.

description: Such a classic, traditional perfect place to take out of town guests for a delicious Italian meal.  All of our dishes were excellent  but the bruschetta and tiramisu stand out.  It is crowded and busy at all times but once you get to your cozy table it is so worth the wait.
author: Carrie B.

description: There hasn't been a trip down union on the 45 that I hadn't thought of how lovely it might be to try the mysterious little restaurant under the green awning. I had high hopes, and left happy. The food was just a bit less delicious than the atmosphere, but not much. I had the capellini pomodorro.  It could have used a little more tomato sauce and less tomatoes, but the ambiance made up for it. It was pretty good, but not quite as interesting as the pictures on the wall next to us. Retro and not fake about it like Bucca Di Beppo. The wine list was also a bit limited. This is no A16, think mom and pop Italian place with no interest in battling wine lists with the best of em. I might suggest ordering a bottle over a glass as they seem to only offer kenwood-esque replicas ala carte.  I have nothing but great things to say about this place. I will go back again and again.
author: Michelle K.

description: Hands down the best italian food in North Beach.
author: rahmin s.

description: This place is reliable great Italian food. The rigatoni is amazing. The peppers are great too. Good selection of main entrees and great pastas. Terrific wine selection - both Italian and Californian wines. I will go back and always recommend. Also TC is not too expensive.
author: elizabeth s.

description:
Looking for good Italian for a group of out of town guests. We found it at Trattoria Contadina. Booked with open table for a group of 8 on a Saturday night, we were on time and our table was ready when we arrived - not something to take for granted for such a large group. 

We were seated up stairs with 3 similar sized groups. Talk about cozy - it was more or less shoulder to shoulder. 

Service was really fast and the food was great. Salads are huge - be smart and get a "small" if it's going to be a starter. The hit of the night was the risotto - this night it had tomatoes, chicken (and lots of it) and tons of cheese.
author: Jon F.

description: Excellent food, staff, and overall experience.  The sauces on their pastas have some of the fullest flavors I've ever had the chance to enjoy.  Prices are pretty reasonable given the quality of the food; you're looking at $11-15 for pasta, $15-20 for meat dishes.  I probably get take-out from this place twice a week.  Best italian in Little Italy, no question.
author: Matt O.

description: I've never been disappointed with this North Beach trattoria.  This is a hot spot for locals and its a bit away from the tourist traps of North Beach.  The service and food are excellent.  The stuffed pepper for appetizer is definitely a must have - it's the owner's grandma's recipe.  Atmosphere is fun with crowded tables and a very small bar to have a glass a wine while waiting for your table.  Reservations are recommended.
author: Keith S.

description: I had friends come into town that insisted we go to this place. I don't ever go to North Beach and if I do I have to be pretty drunk. Which I was. BUT even though I was so drunk that I couldn't speak during dinner, it was still one of the best Italian meals I have had since I moved here. The food and the customer service was amazing. I wish I could remember more details but I have their business card in my wallet and I'm looking for any excuse to go back.
author: Jessica S.

description: Okay Italian eatery, but I don't understand all the hype. I've had people tell me that this is their fave Italian joint in the city. Not the case for me. The food was decent, but not out of this world. I had the sauteed red snapper and sampled the prawn and penne pasta as well as the spaghetti and meatballs. The mushroom soup was also a let down, watery and too salty (and I like the salt). Let's see, I can't remember what I had for dessert and it was two nights ago. Enough said.
author: Defne A.

description: My favorite Italian restaurant in the city, hands down!  I've been going here for over 10 years now and every time it never disappoints.  I even had the great pleasure of living a mere 1/2 block away at one point... ah, those were the days.  Service, ambiance, food, bartender, etc are all always suburb.  My favorite dish is the Gnocchi alla Napolentana... pure heaven.  I have tried many a Gnocchi at other places and none even come close to comparing to Trattoria Contadina's.  The last time I visited I also tried their Pepperoni Arrostiti con Formaggio antipasta which just about knocked me off my seat it was so darn good.  How can you go wrong with sweet bell peppers layered with two kinds of cheese complimented by a creamy tomato sauce... mmmm.
author: Ms. M. M.

description:
The tables are uncomfortably close to one another at Trattoria Contadina.  So close that the first and last time I went, my date and I became involuntarily privy to the most intimate details--and the emotional rollercoaster--that formed the relationship backbone of the two-timing couple next to us.

Aside from our unfortunate proximity to this illicit intrigue, the food was good.
author: Hannah J.

description:
actually i think 3.5 stars is more appropriate.

its kind of hit and miss with this restaurant, as some of the dishes are really tasty, but not for the others.

overall good experience though, only when you know what you want to eat
author: JX S.

description: Visited here upon a referral from a local to try the italian restaurants in this area. Our reservation for 4 was on a Saturday night. The place was packed, probably seats about 40 people total. The place is small and quaint but I think thats what makes it welcoming and charming. Some other reviewes I read on here were not very good but I thought this place was great. The food was very tasty and the service was beyond excellent. We were immediatley seated and served our drinks. We placed our dinner orders, I asked for soup of the day and coffee to come before my meal. We could not believe how quickly our waiter returned with the soup and coffee. I mean literally 1 minute after walking away from our table the waiter returned with hot soup and coffee. Our drinks and bread  were constantly repelensihed and out waiter checked in frequently to see if we needed anything. The prices were reasonable adn portions were large enough as pasta is very filling. 3 of us shared 2 entrees and it was more than enough food.  Other reviews also mentioned parking but we had no problem. There was a parking gargae within 1 block of the restaurant. I woudl give this restaurant a 4-5 star rating.
author: kim h.

description: A happening place with good Italian food.  This restaurant definitely has a family restaurant atmosphere.  It is always usually crowded and loud but it is definitely a good place to go for "homemade" Italian.
author: Shiho F.

description:
So tasty!  Ate here on Saturday night for the 2nd time and it was as good as I remembered it.  Had the table squeezed in between the bar and the window, which was great for people watching.  You also get the added benefit of not being jostled constantly by the other patrons as they inch by you trying to get to the one tiny bathroom shared by both sexes.  We shared a platter of the ethereal gnocchi in a tomato cream sauce and then went on to some wonderful salads.  I had a HUGE arugula and radicchio salad with pecans and Gorgonzola. Although it's pretty much a staple on the menu of many Italian restaurants, this one was much better than I've had recently.   Onto the entrees, which for me was a giant hunk'o halibut cooked with a tomato ragout with tasty grilled potatoes and an assortment of fresh veggies.  We told the cute and attentive waitress (who was rockin' the Gwen Stefani look) that we couldn't eat another bite - so she brought us dessert in a glass - some sort of Italian wine liquor mixed with hot chocolate and foam.  The perfect topper to the meal.

One star off for the sometimes slow service.
author: .Hon H.

description:
overall a great italian restaurant. the service was really good, our waiter even recommended downsizing the gnocchi order b/c we had ordered a carb-heavy polenta to begin with. plus he took the fact that i dropped an entire glass of water on the floor in stride. 

ordered the polenta, ceaser salad, gnocchi and roasted veal filet with porcini mushrooms. polenta and gnocchi were total standouts. the yelp reviews are right, the gnocchi was among the best i've tasted. okay but, if i had to be picky, it could have been a little smaller. by the time you chewed through to the middle, all the sauce flavor was gone. it's still like a 9.9 out of 10, i'm just hoping that the chef reads this and adjusts accordingly. :)

the one complaint i have is that the roasted veal filet with porcini mushrooms was much too dry, even when doused in the sauce. unfortunate end to an overall great meal. but i've heard the "vitella saltimbucca" (veal scaloppini layered with prosciutto) is much much better, so will have to go back and give that a try!
author: Jessica W.

description: Years ago, this was a decent little hole in the wall Italian joint -  Cozy atmosphere, kind of dark and romantic/ pretty good food for the price. I recently took some friends from out of town and it was ridiculously bad. $16.00 for an antipasto plate that was awful. My pasta was drowning in sauce that was flavorless, eggplant was not cooked, pasta had no flavor. Everyone else at table could barely eat their dishes as well. Dont know if they have changed hands but this was THE WORST Italian food I think I have ever had. This place makes Olive Garden look like a 4 star restaurant. Owners please review your chefs and the food they cook - it simply is horrible.
author: G K.

description: Growing up with a Nona has made me hesitant to go out and pay for, what is usually, crapo Italiano cuisine...but this place was a pleasant surprise.  I had the gnocchi, just to see how it would compare to Nona's rendition and the taste was spot on!  More about the potato and less about the flower...I loved it!  I had the polenta with wild mushroom and fontina cheese for starters which was excellent and, of course, tiramisu for dessert!  It was all wonderful...a slice of heaven I tell you!  The service was great, vino list was good enough...but the food is the real star here...just a little fix-up on the ambiance (I don't mind the family feel, but the random garbage upstairs needs to go)and this place would be an easy 5 stars!!!
author: Sarah D.

description: Hmm, since I live in North Beach maybe my love for italian food has been saturated with all the options. The food is good here, but not as good as i've heard from my North Beach neighbors. We had the Prosciutto e Frutta Stagionale (prosciutto with melon), Ravioli alla Salvatore (stuffed with chicken, spinach and cheese), Piccata di Vitello (veal w/ penne pasta). The prosciutto was the best of the three followed by the ravioli and then the veal. The sauces were all decent, but maybe it was just an off night for me...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
No photos tonight, sorry to any readers here.
But we did show up with a group of 4 so I had a chance to see and taste a variety of foods.
So, first of all, if you are transporting yourself to this restaurant, try not to drive because parking is difficult to say the least.  But there is good public transit all around including the Mason Street Cable car which passes the restaurant and would make a nice ride/destination for tourists. Also, buses on Columbus avenue serve well.
  The service was excellent, so no complaints about that.
The menu presents with typical Italian protocol, antipasti, primi piatti and secondi piatti.  we chose prosciuto and carpacchio di manzo, both fresh and excellent.  Lots of capers on my carpacchio.  Two of us ordered the rissoto special with prawns. The prawns were nicely cooked and there were 6 of them circumferentially on the rissoto. The rissoto was OK, but I found I had to add salt.  One of us had the scallops which were fresh and tender and I'd recommend this dish over the rissoto.  And finally we had a clam with linguini in tomato sauce.  Also highly recommended.  The only reason I'm not giving five stars is because I'd like my food a bit more spicy or flavored.  But this could be five stars for some eaters.
author: Jerome W.

description: The problem with eating food this good, is the neagtive shadow it casts other food.  I mean I probably should have just consumed cyanide after eating here, but ultimately decided against it.  But seriously this place is worth dealing with the North Beach scene to spend a couple of hours consuming amazing fare.
author: Eagan I.

description: Literally one of my favorite italian places in the city, this little restaurant is right in north beach and offers some of the best italian food and wine at a really affordable price.  To top it off, the staff is always charming and friendly and the ambiance is very cozy and welcoming.  One thing, sometimes it's hard to get a reservation, so I would definitely recommend calling early if you want to make sure to get in!
author: Liz L.

description:
The food was excellent.    I tried the seafood contadina - it was well balanced with the right spices and sauce.  I finished all the sauce mopping the dish with the bread.   
It was packed on a hot Wed night.    I wished they had air conditioning.  The service was OK but for a packed place, I guess I should not complain.
author: Barry Y.

description: Great place.  It is a bit small, but I loved the cozy atmosphere.  Their pasta was amazing.  When it was first served I looked at the plate and thought, "Ohhh I am never going to make it throught this.  I should not have had a salad."  And then I started to eat and continued to slurp until that whole plate was clean.  I liked the fact that even though this restaurant is in the middle of a section of town that is known for Italian food, they have stayed true to their customers and stayed non touristy.  It just seems to me that the bigger establishments down the block seem to have lessened the quality of their food and it comes off as just food for the masses.  This is a place that I can't wait to bring my closest friends and family to so they can experience some authentic Italian cooking and friendly service.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Highly recommended. This is a very busy place, and when you eat there you quickly find out why. Excellent bar. Fabulous gnocchi appetizer and veal saltimbocca. Warm atmosphere. Excellent service.
author: Ted D.

description: Cozy Italian restaurant.  I would say this is definitely more of a local place than a tourist trap.  I came with a girlfriend, although this place would be great for a date as well. Best Italian restaurant I have been to SF!! Around $33 per person for a nice plate and one glass of wine.  I had the veal fillet topped with mushrooms served with a bed spinach and garlic mashed potatoes.  It was FABULOUS.  I couldn't finish everything and I'm usually pretty good at finishing my plate :) The veal was super tender and tasted amazing.  My friend got the seafood pasta which was great as well.  The red sauce definitely had a SPICY kick to it and they were generous with all the different types of seafood that came in it..
author: Jenny W.

description: I really liked the ambiance! My salad was pretty good but nothing out of the ordinary. The pasta was fine but nothing too exceptional. I've definitely had better. The service was great, though. I think that I'll continue to explore North Beach before I head back here.
author: Monica D.

description:
Simply the best.
It's all about the pasta, however the service is also top notch.
author: gavin f.

description: I'm the Tratt's #1 fan . . .now if only the owners will recognize this and put my picture on the wall. I don't know why it took me so long to Yelp about this place given the fact that I've gone there almost a dozen times in the past few months. Perhaps I wanted to keep it to myself, but it looks like the secret's out. I can't go 2 weeks without craving their beef carpaccio and fettucine vongole . . .mMmm, even though I was just there this past Saturday, I can't wait to go back already. Perfect place to bring friends who are visiting from out of town, to celebrate a special occasion, or for no reason at all other than to enjoy a truly amazing Italian meal.
author: Alice P.

description: My wife and kids are visiting San Fran for a few days and the concierge at the Fairmont Ghiradelli recommended this place.  Great find.  LOTS of garlic, decent service.  My Linguini Vongole was excellent.
author: Gregg W.

description: For Italian style food in SF, this is one of my favorites (good food at SF-reasonable prices) that was recommended by a food friend.  I've been here about 15 times with different friends, families and out of town visitors.  About 13 times the food and service was terrific!  A few times, one person in the group was not too thrilled with their meal.  As for me, I've always had a great meal here.  The place is small with limited tables and getting a reservation on the weekend can be tough, so plan ahead.  Sometimes I call and request a table for an early dinner and they usually can squeeze us in.
author: Marlene B.

description:
hardly that good...

we were in town visiting and i used my trusty yelp app on mon iphone in order to find a nice italian place for our departing dinner...you yelpers really love this place and i am still trying to figure out what all the hub bub is about!

aside from super friendly service, the food was only minorly ok...super over priced bruschetta, which was good...but seven bucks for TWO pieces of bread topped with tomatoes? we ordered three orders for the whole table (because they only come two slices to an order) and wound up spending over twenty bucks for less than half a loaf of bread covered in market veggies...thats ridiculous on any level, in any neighborhood.

the ceasar salad was ok. not my speed since it was overpoweringly fishy...

a girlfriend and i split the eggplant appetizer and the gnocchi with creamy tomato sauce. the eggplant was good. fairly priced, even. the gnocchi...while she really enjoyed it...was tough to me. gnocchi should be soft and creamy, melt in your mouth with just the slightest hint at firm bite...this was like eating tiny pasta-flavored jujubes...

i did like the fact that half orders of pasta were available...and i did like the two bites of my sister's meatball that she shared with me...but four and five stars, people? really? am i truly to believe this is the best SF has to offer in regards to italian fare?

i certainly hope not.
author: becky d.

description: I wanted to go to L'osteria del Forno but it was closed on Tuesday.  From Yelp I thought this place would offer similarly good food, but am very disappointed and will not return.  Food was bland and non-memorable.  Had seafood pasta ($19) and caprese salad ($13).   Waiter dropped off the caprese without offering pepper, dropped off the pasta but never checked back to see if we needed anything else.  We then observed the same waiter dropped off the caprese and offered pepper for the table near us.  Perhaps different attitude for people who ordered alcohol while we didn't.  I don't think a chain is good but Pasta Pomodoro can offer better pasta and service than what we received at this restaurant.
author: SJ E.

description:
On second try, i dig.....  We sat uspstairs this time and the dishes we got were very good.  Service was also excellent.  

Twas a good decision to give this place a 2nd try...
author: Richard C.

description:
I wish they had 4.5 stars here.  I was a first timer last night and I have to say it was great and I am excited to come back again.  This place would be great for a date night.  Only draw back is make sure to call for reservation and took alittle time to finally sit and I felt pretty crowded while sitting but maybe that was because we were in the middle of the restauarant but if I moved my arm I eneded up like hitting someone half the time who was walking by.  
The food was very delcious.  I am not a usual big fan of Italian food but this was good.  We had for starters two great appetizers of Carpacio Di Bresola whic was thinly sliced beef that was awesome as welll as Melanzane alla Mozzarella which was hot eggplant in a great sauce and melted Mozzelera on top of it.  May sound sketchy but really good.  For main courses we both got pastas and they were great.  The Ravioli all Salvatore had Chicken and was good but probally next time will try something else instead of that dish but definetely will get the Gnocchi alla Napoloatan again.  Great fresh Gnocchi with melted cheese and amazing sauce.  Hard to describe but it was awesome.  Desserts looked good but we were too full and plenty of good wines.  Ours was a great red wine.  Look forward to going back and I would say again great date place that will cost about 75 -90 bucks for a good meal for two and a solid bottle of wine.  Enjoy this place.  I am sure I will be back.
author: Harry E.

description:
I love, love, love this cute,cozey,family-owned restaurant. This past February, my boyfriend and I took a trip to San Francisco for our 3 year anniversary and we feel in love with the city and we had the perfect last night cap-off at Trattoria Contadina. 

The staff was helpful and very attentive. The bread is delicious. Although the tables are very close (close enough we could hear the couple next to us fighting, buttttt after a few glasses of vino it became very entertaining for my beau and I). The closeness will add to the homey feeling of this restaurant. 

Next time we visit San Fran I will definately make a stop at this amazing restaurant.
author: T A.

description: Made a reservation here for my daughter's 18th birthday along with 5 of her friends. When I called to confirm, I asked if they could put together something for dessert to commemorate the night since I wouldn't be there to order it. They brought out a beautifully decorated platter with 4 different sweets, mint and a candle! So impressed. The group said their dinner was amazing and the highlight of their entire time in the City!!
author: lisa m.

description: Best North Beach restaurant hands down.  Fantastic atmosphere on a windswept hill above the slums of touristy Columbus.  Although certainly stuck in the 80s, this place is cozy and feels very Californian (bathed in the Golden Sun overlooking the Pacific).  The food and service are wonderful.  Only knock is its kind of spendy, but really, compared to the other tourist traps on Columbus the prices aren't too bad.
author: Kevin G.

description: Some dishes are really good, others are kinda whatever.  It's always crowded for dinner so make a reservation.  The Rigatoni ______ is my favorite there.  Take the 41,45 or Cable car.
author: Nagoo N.

description: I'd never remember the food if it wasn't for the bug in it. Yesterday my wife and I took my parents out for dinner. it was my Dad's 67th birthday so I wanted to take him somewhere nice.  Having read the reviews and dined here one time about a year ago I thought this would be perfect. Well... it was a disaster. First we were ushered into a tiny, hot upstairs room full of screaming children. I asked the less-than-enthusiastic host to be reseated, perhaps by the window where there was a large table for four. After a few minutes we were led to another table downstairs, close to the kitchen. No window, but OK. We ordered the food and a bottle of wine. Half way through the meal I noticed something swimming in my spinach. It was a bug. Yes, a bug. Legs, striped back, whatever.. a bug. Not a small bug, but the kind that looked like a cock roach. I'm not an entomologist, but yeah... it looked like a roach. I alerted the waiter, he took the plate away, came  back a few minutes later and gave me a "sorry man, it happens". That's craptacular. We immediately asked for our check and handed him two Amex cards to pay the bill. He comes  back a few minutes later and says "we were told not to take American Express". So I say to him: "So... do you accept American Express"? He says: "Yes". So I say: "But you were TOLD not to"?  He says: "Yes". OK.. we're outta here. We gave him 2 alternate cards, zero tip and walked the hell out of there. So let me wrap it up: the food here is not that good. It would be somewhat impressive if you were in Fargo, North Dakota, but this is San Francisco, it was lame. The service was crap. The seating and ambiance is even worse crap. There are thousands upon thousands of restaurants in this city. Don't go to this one.
author: Andrew M.

description: We went to Italian town for dinner with a local family.  Yup, it's Italian. Proclaimed very simple by far  but it's definitely comfort food for me. And when the stars align to make comfort food extra awesome via great cooks
author: Mark T.

description: My Wife and i here on a trip to San Fransisco, and it was excellent. The place is very cozy and slightly loud. The Ravioli was delicious, the waiter attentive even though it was very busy. I highly recommend this place.
author: Dylan N.

description: You know I have some really fond mems here.  This place was in my hood and I really just loved everything for what it was.  Friendly people, good rich food and fun times.  I miss you old pal...
author: Rachel P.

description: Such a great neighborhood restaurant.  The caesar salad is great, and the Rigotoncelli alla Carlesimo is amazing (pancetta, porcini mushrooms, sundried tomatoes in a vodka tomato sauce).  The waiter suggested that on my first visit as one of their best pastas - I have never ordered anything else since.  It's also such a nice, warm and very cozy (tables are close together) place.  It's inexpensive, so you can drop in on a week night for a quick dinner, or make a date of it on a weekend (if you can get a reservation).
author: Lauren S.

description: So this is my parents' favorite Italian restaurant in the city and every time they come up, like this weekend,  they want to go here.  It is really good, fancy, simple Italian food, if they weren't paying I would probably would go to Emmy's or to Cafe Macaroni.  But hot damn they make a mean veal parm here and their sauce is killer.
author: Katie M.

description: We ate there tonight after having not been for about ten years.  The place, as another reviewer wrote, is not the same.  And the food was not good.  It lacked flavor so badly;  We all three had different pasta dishes and a couple of salads.  The salads were okay, Misto and Caesar, they were not great, and the pasta dishes were so bland that we had to add salt and pepper which is unheard of at a good Italian restaurant.  The pastas were spaghetti and meatballs,  Cavatapi with shrimp and scallops, and linguine with sausage.  They were not made well at all, we were kind of shocked -- so disappointed at how the food had totally changed from back in the mid- late 90s when they must have had a much better chef.  Oh well, we have our memories but will not be back to eat there again. It was bordering on being a waste of money.
author: Steve B.

description: Just when I was about to give up on Italian fare in North Beach, I found Trattoria Contadina. Excellent food (the chicken ravioli was probably my favorite), good wine list (a 2001 Gary Farrell Cab for $50!) and friendly service. I'm happy it's so close to my place, because I will definitely be back!
author: Brianne K.

description: Hands down one of the best Italian restaurants in the city, Trattoria Contadina serves up healthy portions of simple, delicious southern italian food.  The wait staff is great...I would say some of the best service in the city.  This tiny restaurant is a block off the beaten path of Columbus and a favorite among locals, for good reason!  Start out with the roasted bell peppers stuffed with 3 cheeses, covered in a spicy tomato cream sauce...oh my mouth waters just thinking of it!!  My personal favorite dishes are the Rigitone Carlisimo and the Chicken Valdostana....finish it off with their signature desert drink - the Totara!  Yum, yum!!
author: Jessica T.

description: Very friendly staff and noisy atmosphere.  Reserve in advance! it's always booked. Great place to go before heading out for the night to North Beach.
author: Dev K.

description:
3.5 stars if possible.

Two of us friends came here with reservations in tow.  This was a good thing because the restaurant was filling up quickly and most everyone had a reservation.

The service here was excellent from both the server and the bus boys.  Our water glasses were never empty and the server was not pushy.  The server was knowledgeable about the wine list and was honest about his favorites and ones that he might pass over - this was depending on what we were in the mood for and what we were planning to order.

Regarding the wine, a lovely selection.  However, review the label prior to corking because similar to Le Petit Laurent, the year may be off by a year.  Why pay a 2004 price when you're served 2005?

We ordered the bruschetta as an appetizer.  For $7 we thought that we would get the typical 4-5 slices or so.  There are two (2) slices per order.  At $3.50 per piece, we had never eaten our bruschetta more slowly than we did that evening.  It was delicious, though.  The bread was crispy without being too hard to bite into and the tomato topping was perfectly portioned as to not spill all over.  The tomatoes had been chopped into conveniently-sized bits that did not make for slobber potential.

The main courses are very reasonably priced at $12-18 per plate.  This excludes meat dishes since we had only ordered pasta dishes, thus I cannot comment on anything else.

The Pavarotti played a soothing counter-balance of smooth mildness to the spicy and bold Carlesimo.  Both were well seasoned and the flavors in each dish complimented each other well.

Each dessert is $7 (again, how can a 2-piece bruschetta cost $7 when you get a whole dessert for the exact same cost).  

If you've had dinner already and are looking for a super quaint off-the path of the hussle and bussle of Columbus, then come here for a dessert and an after dinner drink to cap off the night.
author: Kristina M.

description: Went in tonight with a party of 7. We were greeted warmly by the host (the son of the owner I believe...the third generation, a true family business). The place was busy but our table was ready right on time. I had gotten there a few minutes early and had a glass of wine at the bar. I wish the 'by the glass' selection was a bit more robust but the wine list in general was good and the prices somewhat reasonable. We started off with some appetizers, mostly antipasto. Very good but we were surprised that they didn't offer calamari. Excellent lentil soup which we ordered on the recommendation of our excellent server, Nancy. As a group, we were a bit loud and, fueled by a day that was not without beer, extra charming. I really love it when I go out with a group of people and we're having a good time and the server does not attempt to either be a giant buzzkill to register disapproval or, worse, be 'one of the gang.' Nancy was perfect. Excellent chicken parmigiana. It wasn't on the menu, only veal was but they did a great job with it. Wonderful sauce, just the right amount of cheese and the side veggies were flavorful. We were seated at 6:30 and didn't get up until 9 but never felt rushed. It was a reunion of sorts for a group of us who hadn't been together for more than 10 years. We had a fantastic evening. TC was the perfect place. Great vibe, great food and great service.
author: Brian B.

description: I recently dined at Trattoria while visiting friends in San Francisco. I absolutely LOVE Italian food, and this did not disappoint! The atmosphere is cozy and quaint, a neighborhood intimate feel. The restaurant was crowded on Saturday night, but we were promptly greeted by the owner who found us a seat in the house in no time. For starters the Pepporoni Arrostiti was amazing! The creaminess of the different melted cheeses complemented the spicy tomato cream sauce to really bring out the sweet bell pepper flavor. The bruschetta tasted fantastic with the ripest tomatoes! We also tried the meatballs- which I am a HUGE critic of meatballs, and these were top notch full of flavor. So good I even ordered a side of meatballs to go with my pasta dish! For salad I ordered the caprese salad, mozzerela cheese was so fresh- beautiful presentation. For entree the Gnocchi was fabulous. Perfect pillows of pasta, fluffy and oh-so-yummy! Great flavor with the rich tomato cream sauce. The only downfall of the night was I ate too much (as you can tell by all of the food we had!) that I couldn't bear to finish the night off with dessert...but it sure did look good! Overall, great service, amazing food, lovely atmosphere, timely service, very polite owners. Perfect place for catching up with friends, spending a lovely meal with family, or date night. I will eat here every time I am in San Francisco!
author: Jennifer T.

description:
a little out of the chaos that is north beach, is great little trattoria known as contadina.  contadina is a friendly, cozy neighborhood joint with some of the best italian in the area!  the people are charming, and the space is homey.

no frills here, people, just great food!
author: Jill k.

description: Charming North Beach Italian that serves up great fare with attentive service.  Off the beaten path and conspicuously absent of tourists, this is a great place to get some true San Francisco flavor.
author: Aaron A.

description: I think the food could've been better but maybe I just need to give them a second chance. I will give it three stars for their cozy atmosphere off the beaten path in North Beach and their friendly service. I also enjoyed seeing the cable cars roll right in front of us through the windows during dinner. Good neighborhood spot but just the food could afford to be stepped up a notch!
author: Anne E.

description:
amidst all the mediocre italian food in north beach, sits the trattoria contadina. i think it's physical location is a perfect metaphor for where it ranks in quality and taste...it's up the hill, away from all the other places, and definitely above many of the other NB tourist traps. 

aside from it being totally bistro-charming inside, the service is friendly and the food is so good you might just leave with a stomachache because you couldn't stop eating. 

we shared the cesar salad to start along with the polenta and mushrooms, which was fabulous. i had the ravioli correnti, which was nice and pillowy, with just the right amount of chew to it. it was stuffed with spinach and pork and beef and egg and cheese in a creamy mushroom sauce. i mean, come on. yum. 

the husband got the Rigatoncelli all Carlisimo, with peas and pancetta and porcinis in a spicy tomato cream sauce. his was also really good. both were very heavy though, and we had to reign ourselves in to keep from overdoing it. when they say creamy sauce they mean it. but the portions are not ridiculously large so you never feel like a pig. we also shared a really nice barbera that at $30ish was a great deal. 

if you can eat dessert here, you might have an eating problem. but still, if you do, let me know how it is. we had to pass.
author: rachel p.

description: The food here is great....just a few steps from the Italian-Restaurant Row in North Beach but more authentic and flavorful than all the rest. I love the contadina sauce! I do, however feel like the quality has slipped a bit in recent years.
author: Sara W.

description: FANTASTIC.  Milo was our server and he was 100 percent top notch.  The place is adorable and the food delicious.  I had the seafood stew.  So yummy.  FYI . . you get half an ocean's worth of seafood, so make sure you arrive with a very empty tummy.  It is a perfect place to go before Beach Blanket.
author: Marla L.

description: I agree.  This place isn't for locals but I keep coming back because the food is pretty damn good.  Nothing REALLY fancy but the menu is fairly priced and comprehensive.  The stuffed peppers are a must.  Really.
author: Thadd L.

description: I always walked by this place and it smelled so good from the outside. I finally ate here and it was really good. Food was tasty, service was great and the ambience was fun and energetic. Ravioli in cream sauce was amazing as well as the Rigotincello with panchetta in spicy tomato sauce.
author: Peter K.

description: Good Italian...Attentive service. More of a family crowd and old fashioned atmosphere.
author: Colleen M.

description: Fun, loud Italian joint.  Must have the 4-cheese stuffed pepper appetizer - one of my favorites in the city.
author: Max C.

description: For a more formal meal I would go to Trattoria Contadina.. The pasta dishes are great..
author: Trish P.

description: Really disappointed by this place.  Really cozy, has a great vibe.  I had heard so much about it, but food was just mediocre.  This is the kind of stuff that is good for tourists, but much better Italian can be found in the city.  This is the kind of place I would go get a drink at, then bounce to get food.
author: Kapeli M.

description: Bomb ass Italian food, just like how a wannabe Italian mobster like me likes it. Ordered the calamari appetizer but it wasn't that great. The calamari was so tiny, I could wear it on my pinky finger. The roasted chicken breast was just dandy. Juicy, flavorful, and succulent, just like how great breasts should be. The pizza wasn't too bad but there should have been more toppings. Nice fresh dough though. I suggest going there for good Italian pasta. Nice location too. You can go check out a topless club after you chow down on some rigatoni.
author: Steve S.

description: We went on a Friday night, it was packed.  This restaurant seems to be the smallest restaurant ever until you realize there is a second floor.  Highly recommend the Pepperoni Arrostiti con Formaggio as an appetizer, it was so good.  Limited wine by the glass selection which was a bummer.  Quick service, definitely would return.
author: Marc M.

description: This place was awesome...wish they had it in So Cal! There were way too many restaurants for us to choose from in SF, but somehow this one stood out in our guidebook, and it still stands out in my mind as excellent Italian! I would definitely recommend making reservations, the place is tiny...but really cozy and a great atmosphere. Being a tourist, I loved how we could see the cable cars go by out the restaurant window. And the food...so good! I had a hard time choosing from the wonderful menu, but ultimately chose the Rigantoncelli alla Carlesimo. It was rigatoncelli pasta with sauteed pancetta, porcini mushrooms, peas, sun-dried tomatoes, and a spicy tomato cream sauce. We have unsuccessfully attempted to recreate this dish at home...guess I'll just have to make a weekend of it and go to SF to dine at Trattoria Contadina once more!
author: Amy C.

description: This place is by far my favorite Italian restaurant in SF. Don't miss it. It's right next to the cable car line, and oh so delicious! I highly recommend everything on the menu! I love the location, and the atmosphere is soo quaint, and charming. You feel right at home. The dessert menu is quite nice too.
author: Mei F.

description: The food here is pretty good. The servings are the right size, probably a bit on the larger side. The flavor is classic. I believe the cook actually goes through a tastes his own food before serving it. I don't enjoy looking for parking, but I came here one night and the maitre'd squeezed us in and even let me park in the passenger zone for the evening. The waiter was really nice and attentive. My fettucine was good, but my girlfriends' rigatoncelli was excellent. She didn't like the wateriness of the sauce, but I couldn't keep my fork on my side of the plate.
author: Wil M.

description: If you like the old, classic Italian style food and restaurant, this is a great place to go.  If you're looking for more cutting edge, A-16 type place, you won't be happy here. I first experienced Trattoria Contandina in 1995 working in the city and have been a huge fan since.  The pasta dishes are absolutely delicious.  I don't order anything but the pasta dishes because they're so good - and the meat dishes are, well ok.  I also wish they would have a little larger, nicer wine glasses.  Aside from that, I love the atmosphere, the service.....can't wait to go back!
author: Grover G.

description: Great food, great wait staff.  Small and quaint, you feel like family when you step in.
author: Cari G.

description: Have eaten hare a couple of times.  Love the ravioli.  Service was a little slow the last time and they could definitely improve on the desserts.  Would still go back when in the area.
author: Tina B.

description: We went here for dinner Sunday evening.  It wasn't bad--but it wasn't great.  The food was pretty ordinary.  We split a manzane alla mozzarella antipasti and then their spaghetti and meatballs.  Maybe we ordered poorly, but neither dish impressed us.  There are plenty of other places in North Beach that we want to try, so I doubt we'll be back here anytime soon.
author: Suman G.
